SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; NATIONAL PERSPECTIVES; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 1240 words

HEADLINE: Old Mills That Aren't Run of the Mill

BYLINE: By LISA CHAMBERLAIN

DATELINE: Easthampton, Mass. 

 BODY:
IN urban areas across the country, former manufacturing buildings have been undergoing renovation for some time. But in an outpost like western Massachusetts, the heart of the Industrial Revolution in America, where the economy still struggles and the population has dwindled since its heyday, urban revitalization is just now arriving at the doorstep.
 Old industrial mills built on a system of rivers and canals have dotted the picturesque landscape for 150 years, but now these cavernous hulks of bricks and mortar are in the early stages of being renovated and reoccupied as large-scale mixed-use complexes and residential lofts. In other words, these historic structures are at the heart of a different revolution: the changing landscape of how Americans live, work and play -- and not a moment too soon for the Pioneer Valley.
Easthampton, a town of 16,000 people about 100 miles west of Boston, has been struggling to revive itself for decades, after manufacturing jobs left the area en masse. 
 The first evidence of such a revival, however, seems to have happened almost accidentally. Will Bundy, a mill-conversion pioneer, bought an old Fuller Brush building in 1997 for $650,000 and renamed it Eastworks with plans to turn the space into a cluster of large-scale arts-related industries. It didn't quite work out that way. ''We put off residential until we realized it was the hottest part of the property,'' Mr. Bundy said on a tour of what is now an almost completely renovated 500,000-square-foot mill that overlooks a significant local landmark, Mount Tom. (Mr. Bundy initially owned the property with a partner whom he later bought out.) 
 ''Initially, we were going to only have commercial and rent to large-scale tenants,'' Mr. Bundy said. ''But everyone wanted smaller spaces. Just as soon as we converted some of the space to accommodate smaller users, they immediately began asking about live-work space. So it evolved.''
 Mr. Bundy is now overseeing the final phase of the building's transformation into a mix of ground-floor retail space, a second floor of arts- and industry-related businesses, and a top floor of apartments. He is completing 17,000 more square feet of studio space, as well as 15 more loft-style apartments, in addition to the 32 already built.
 Eastworks is home to an eclectic mix of businesses and residents, from law offices to a comic book collector and illustrator, a fabric designer, photographers and painters, a meditation center and massage studio, a handbag designer, a jeweler, a book collector and a software designer. A vast majority of them could not exist in an outpost like Easthampton without the reach of the Internet to sustain their businesses.
 Julius Ford, who moved to the area from Harlem with his wife, Debora Ferreira, three years ago, knew they wanted to move with their 2-year-old son, Phoenix Ryzen, from their traditional place in Amherst as soon as he saw Eastworks in September 2005. 
 ''It really is the perfect mix of city life and country life,'' said Mr. Ford, an artist and small-business owner, who works from home as an events planner and human relations consultant.
 ''We pay $1,300 a month for 2,600 square feet with huge windows that face Mount Tom,'' Mr. Ford continued. ''But here I have an office at home and a small gallery space, so it's no problem for people to come up and look at my artwork. Downstairs, I can get groceries or go to the restaurant, which is really nice in the winter. And the kids here love it, running up and down the wide factory hallways and visiting with neighbors. You wouldn't think it would be conducive for family life, but it works.''
 Paul Kuhn and Van Outlaw opened their business, Men of Iron, where they make architectural home and garden fixtures in a shop on the second floor in Eastworks. Soon afterward, they moved into a loft apartment that they have since fixed up, while keeping their shop.
 ''I didn't have the imagination to expect that people would become multiple tenants,'' Mr. Bundy said.
 Another development in Easthampton, Paradise One, is a gay and lesbian retirement community that is being planned for an old mill just a stone's throw from Eastworks.
 Heather and Nancy Whitley had been working on their dream of such a community, with high-tech amenities and 24-hour concierge service, for two years when they came across an old mill for sale. The owner, David L. Murphy, had taken over a troubled loan on the building and planned to sell it when he was approached by the Whitleys about becoming the developer for their idea of a retirement community. 
 ''We have a vision, but we're not developers,'' said Nancy Whitley, ''so we partnered with David. We want to augment human caregiving with technology, and develop a retirement community for people who might not have as many family members to help them in their elder years.'' 
 Renovations will begin later this summer on the 120,000-square-foot mill, which will become approximately 80 condominium units. The development, in partnership with Intel, the chipmaker, will offer health-care-related technology, like bed sensors that monitor weight and mobility and send information wirelessly to health workers. 
 Paradise One is expected to open in 2008. 
 Down the road from Easthampton is Holyoke, an early planned industrial city, incorporated in 1850. It was once home to some of America's richest citizens but is now the poorest city in Massachusetts. Built on a system of canals that draw water from the Connecticut River, the city can accommodate 200,000 people but now has a population of only 40,000. Most downtown residential housing is subsidized units for low-income families. Yet, there are rumblings of a revitalization.
 The very first mill built in the area is slowly being transformed into a huge mixed-use complex by John Aubin, whose father bought the property in 1969. Several years ago, Mr. Aubin, an architect, moved from New York City to fulfill his father's dream of bringing the 700,000-square-foot building back to life. 
 Located on eight and a half acres along one of the main canals, the building, which still gets some of its power from historic waterwheels, is now home to 45 businesses, from an educational theater company to a Hispanic-owned bilingual newspaper (42 percent of Holyoke's residents are Hispanic), a marketing firm, a children's furniture designer and several technology-related businesses.
 ''The area is underperforming economically,'' Mr. Aubin said. ''So this would absolutely not be possible to develop on my own without the reach of technology and the Internet. We're recreating a whole community here that could not otherwise exist.'' 
 In addition to setting aside 5 percent of the building's space for subsidized artists' studios, Mr. Aubin is planning residential units as well as a hotel, which he hopes to begin work on within a year. 
 Across the canal from that development is a 50,000-square-foot mill owned by Eric Shuher, who grew up in the area and has been developing commercial real estate in western Massachusetts for years. The mill's renovation will be his first wholly residential project, which he is beginning slowly by first building a model unit to gauge interest and help him decide if it should be rental or condo.
 ''Holyoke is ready to transform itself,'' Mr. Shuher said. ''There's a natural progression under way, and getting market-rate housing downtown is critical.''

HEADLINE: Movies

 BODY:

TREES LOUNGE (1996)
Tuesday at 7:15 a.m. and Saturday at 6 a.m. and 10 p.m. on Sundance
When Steve Buscemi wrote and directed this wrenching portrait of blue-collar suburbia, he could not have cast a better man in the lead: himself. Mr. Buscemi (above, right, with Bronson Dudley) plays Tommy Basilio, an unemployed car mechanic (he ''borrowed'' $1,500 from his boss and got caught) whose life is sliding slowly into an abyss. He spends most of his time at a bar. He mourns the loss of his girlfriend (Elizabeth Bracco), who is now married to his best friend (Anthony LaPaglia) and pregnant, although the paternity of the child is questionable. Reduced to driving an ice cream truck, he finds himself flirting with an under-age neighbor (Chloe Sevigny) and that's a mistake. 


MASH (1970)
Wednesday at 8 p.m. and Thursday at 3 p.m. on AMC
Robert Altman didn't invent Hawkeye Pierce, Trapper John, Radar O'Reilly and Hot Lips O'Houlihan (Richard Hooker did, in his novel), but his direction and Ring Lardner Jr.'s screenplay brought them to unforgettable life. Hawkeye (Donald Sutherland) and Trapper (Elliott Gould, at far left with Mr. Sutherland) are adorably hip, irreverent, martini-drinking surgeons at a mobile army hospital in this very dark Korean War comedy. (The theme song is ''Suicide Is Painless.'') When it was released, the film seemed like a comment on the insanity and waste of the Vietnam War, and its message hasn't changed. Happily, after all these years, the film's humor still feels daring. Lardner won an Oscar; Mr. Altman took home the Cannes Film Festival's Palme d'Or.

THE AMERICANIZATION OF EMILY (1964)
Wednesday at 8 p.m. on TCM
Speaking of antiwar movies - if you needed an irreverent script written in the mid-20th century, there was no better man to do it than Paddy Chayefsky, known best for his television work. In this sharp, cynical Chayefsky screenplay, directed by Arthur Hiller, Lt. Cmdr. Charles Madison (James Garner) is a World War II American naval officer in London during the buildup for D-Day. Charlie, a bachelor who prizes his freedom, soon falls in love with an Englishwoman (Julie Andrews, above, with Mr. Garner). A widow, she doesn't think much of Charlie's belief that there's nothing noble about dying a hero.

ROCK SCHOOL (2005)
Wednesday at 9 p.m. and Wednesday/Early Thursday at 1 a.m. on A&E
Paul Green, who operates the Paul Green School of Rock Music in Pennsylvania, is not every parent's idea of a dream teacher. He uses four-letter words, tells his students (including Madi, left) exactly what he thinks of their abilities, talks about Satan a lot and jokingly threatens to kill their families if they don't shape up. Mr. Green's approach with his students, he says in this lively documentary directed by Don Argott, is to ''see what they can do once you strip away the fear and the laziness.'' Sometimes the kids are adorable just for trying. Occasionally one of them is great.

HEADLINE: The Bases Are Loaded 

BYLINE: By DAVE CALDWELL

 BODY:
AS recently as 1993, the New York area was a backwater for minor league baseball. After all, it had the Yankees and the Mets, who between them played a total of 162 home games a year.
 There was one minor league team -- the Red Sox in New Britain, Conn. -- in an area embracing Connecticut, New Jersey and a chunk of New York, including Long Island and Westchester and Dutchess Counties.
Last year the Yankees and the Mets drew a total of 6.9 million fans, 2.7 million more than in 1993. But these days 16 minor league teams share that same swath of land, and at least 3 more are on the way, leading some fans to wonder: How much of a good -- and sometimes not-so-good -- thing can even the most ardent baseball fan stand?
 The fact is, New York City and its suburbs have become a hotbed for minor league baseball, saturating the region with more clubs any other part of the country. And if a trip to a Yankees or Mets game is akin to taking in a Broadway play, then heading to a minor league game is like a trip to a neighborhood cineplex. 
 ''It's Hometown U.S.A.,'' said James P. Molinaro, the borough president of Staten Island, which is home to the Yankees' New York-Penn League team. ''And it gives the parent an opportunity to go out and see some baseball with his family without spending $400.''
 Tickets, as well as peanuts, popcorn and hot dogs, are substantially less expensive in the minors than in the big leagues. The best seat in the house for a Staten Island Yankees game costs $11, compared with a seat at the top of the upper deck of Yankee Stadium, which is $20.
 Of course, players in the minor leagues are far less polished than their big-league counterparts, but most people who go to a game already know that. The quality of play is not much better than it is at, say, a local college game. And the age of most of the players is similar. Only one of the 26 players on the current roster of the BlueClaws, the Philadelphia Phillies' Class A affiliate in Lakewood, N.J., has celebrated his 24th birthday. 
 Still, minor league officials like to say they have built an audience by emphasizing the notion that a night of baseball in Coney Island or Central Islip is affordable family entertainment.
 It is an appeal that has resonated. 
 In 2005, the 16 minor league teams in the area drew a total of 3,835,689 fans, or slightly fewer than the record 4,090,440 the Yankees drew last year while playing in a stadium about 10 times the size of an average minor league park.
 While minor league fans will not see Alex Rodriguez swatting a home run for the Yankees or Pedro Martinez pitching to perfection for the Mets, they might get to cavort with a fuzzy mascot or participate in a three-legged race between innings.
 ''If people leave the park without knowing who won or lost the game, then we have done our job,'' said Jim Beaudoin, the general manager of the Connecticut Defenders of the Eastern League.
 Indeed, minor league baseball has become such a cottage industry that it is now regarded as a way to lure families and large groups into redeveloped areas where baseball is just one attraction. Retail shops, restaurants, office space and hotels are often other parts of the package.
 But a minor league ballpark does not guarantee that the area around it will be developed. For instance, KeySpan Park on Coney Island, where the Brooklyn Cyclones, a Mets farm team, have played to capacity crowds since 2001, does not appear to have changed its surroundings much.
 ''If a ballpark is not part of a larger urban redevelopment, it's not going to be successful,'' said Mary-Jane Foster, a real estate developer who with her husband, Jack McGregor, owns and operates the Bridgeport Bluefish, an Atlantic League team in Connecticut. The couple bought the team in December.
 That lesson has not been lost on Mr. McGregor and Ms. Foster, who own one of three Atlantic League expansion teams on the drawing board. In their case, a ballpark in Yonkers is to be the jewel of a $3.1-billion downtown renovation project.
 The two other proposals for the Atlantic League, which was founded in 1998 and is made up of independent teams with no major league ties, call for new stadiums to be built as part of the redevelopment of the Nassau Coliseum property in Uniondale, and in the Meadowlands Xanadu, a shopping center and entertainment complex going up in the Meadowlands Sports Complex in New Jersey
 For now, Steven B. Kalafer -- a developer and owner of about 30 automobile dealerships who at one time had a stake in every team in the Atlantic League except the Atlantic City Surf -- also owns a New Jersey franchise called the Bergen Cliff Hawks, which he planned to have play at a ballpark at Xanadu. But for now, the financially troubled developers of Xanadu have failed to produce a plan for the park, and Mr. Kalafer is suing them. 
 The Nassau County team, which still does not have a name, will be operated by Frank Boulton, the founder and commissioner of the Atlantic League and the owner of three of its teams, including the Long Island Ducks. The Ducks have played to capacity crowds at the 6,002-seat Citibank Park in Central Islip since the league began in 1998.
 Mr. Boulton does not seem to be concerned that his new team will play its home games just 25 miles west of the Ducks, who drew 429,218 to 70 home dates last season. He conceded in a recent interview that the landscape could become too cluttered with minor league teams, but he insisted that point had not yet been reached. 
 As Mr. Kalafer said, ''The region was simply under-served.''
 That is not to say that owning a minor league team in the region is a ticket to success. 
 Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who is a leading authority on the business of sports, said in a telephone interview that in general, it was hard to have too many minor league teams, since fans prefer to travel only minutes to a game. But he said the New York area might be nearly saturated. 
 ''I'm exaggerating here, but it's a little bit like having a bowling alley in each community,'' said Mr. Zimbalist, the author of ''In the Best Interests of Baseball? The Revolutionary Reign of Bud Selig'' (John Wiley & Sons, $24.95), about the commissioner of Major League Baseball. 
 ''It sounds to me like 16 is too many,'' Mr. Zimbalist said of New York's crop of teams. ''You can certainly have a glut.''
 Take the New Jersey Cardinals, a farm club of the St. Louis Cardinals. At the end of last season, it moved from Sussex County, N.J., to a new ballpark in State College, Pa., where the team will be called the Spikes. 
 Or the Ravens, an Eastern League affiliate of the Toronto Blue Jays, who left New Haven, Conn., for Manchester, N.H., where a new ballpark was completed after the 2003 season.
 ''Yale Field did not have some of the amenities you'd like to have in a modern ballpark,'' said Charlie Dowd, the former general manager of the Ravens, who is now general manager of the Bridgeport Bluefish.
 But just as quickly as teams move to other homes, new ones take their place. Sussex County and New Haven quickly lured franchises from the Can-Am League, another independent league. 
 Those teams have to win over the jilted fans of the previous tenants, of course. ''When a team leaves a city, they're not really anxious to give their love away again,'' said Marie Heikkinen Webb, the general manager of the new team in New Haven, the Cutters. ''We had to earn these fans back.''
 Although the Ducks have always attracted large crowds, some other Atlantic League teams have struggled. The Nashua Pride, in New Hampshire, switched to the Can-Am League during the off-season, obliging the Atlantic League to find a new eighth team to balance its schedule. The new team, the Road Warriors, does not yet have a home field. 
 Another of Mr. Boulton's teams, the Atlantic City Surf, averaged 2,018 fans a game last year at its 5,900-seat stadium, the Sandcastle, and the Newark Bears, owned in part by Mr. Kalafer until late last year, averaged 2,709 at their 6,200-seat home park. 
 And the Bridgeport Bluefish averaged only 3,036 fans a game last season at the 5,300-seat Ballpark at Harbor Yard. Mr. Dowd, the general manager, said the team did not have enough money to advertise last year, a crucial component to success in the minors. 
 Ms. Foster, one of the new owners of the team, said the push is on to make the Bluefish enticing to suburban mothers, who usually make the entertainment decisions for their families.
 ''It has not made money,'' she said of the club. ''But we also believe that it can.''
 Indeed, Ms. Foster says she is so sure of the drawing power of minor league teams that she and her husband plan to run an Atlantic League team in Yonkers starting in 2008. ''We were really amazed at how Yonkers has turned itself around,'' she said.
 At first, the mayor of Yonkers, Philip A. Amicone, simply wanted a minor league park built downtown, surrounded by new shops. But the ballpark plan has become part of a full-fledged redevelopment project for the city of 200,000.
 Even though downtown Yonkers is less than 10 miles from Yankee Stadium and less than 20 miles from Shea, Mayor Amicone says the team will not compete for customers with New York's two big-league teams.
 ''To travel to Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium costs a fortune for a family,'' he said. ''Now, Yonkers is going to be a place where people want to come again.''
 The project, privately financed, is being overseen by a group of developers including Louis Cappelli, a Yonkers native.
 ''They're trying to position Yonkers as a real city -- a 24-hour city,'' said Geoff Thompson, a spokesman for the developers.
 The 6,500-seat ballpark was designed by George Hibbs -- an architect for the Trenton-based firm Clarke Caton Hintz -- who had already designed ballparks in Trenton and Camden.
 The ballpark in Yonkers includes one design element that is substantially different from the stadiums Mr. Hibbs has already designed: It will sit atop a three-story parking garage that will be used during the off-season and when the team is not in town.
 ''It's not taking up additional space somewhere else in town,'' Mr. Hibbs said.
 As for the park itself, Mr. Hibbs said architects of ballparks are somewhat limited in that they all have three bases and a home plate. The challenge is to make them fit in, he said, as he did in Camden, where the two towers in front of Campbell's Field look like the abutments of the adjacent Benjamin Franklin Bridge, which links Camden and downtown Philadelphia. 
 Mr. Hibbs said the Yonkers site is unique because of its proximity to City Hall.
 ''It's a classic approach for a ballpark now, which is to blend it into its surroundings,'' he said. ''Each one has been designed to fit specifically into its locale.''
 The ballparks on the drawing board for the Meadowlands and in Nassau County will not be in the middle of existing urban areas, but the goal is the same: to draw those seeking affordable family entertainment to a site that also has offices, shops and restaurants.
 In fact, a ballpark was not originally included in Charles B. Wang's plan to renovate Nassau Coliseum, the home of his two pro franchises, the Islanders of hockey and the Dragons of arena football. 
 In addition to a refurbished arena and a sports technology center, Mr. Wang, the founder of Computer Associates, wants to build office towers, hotels, apartment buildings and town houses on the site.
 Mr. Wang and Reckson Associates, his development partner, were awarded the project last month over a rival bid by the owners of the Mets, in part because they added a minor league ballpark to their plan to match the one the Mets proposed.
 When he announced that the Wang and Reckson partnership had won, Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, declared, ''There must be baseball.''
 And so there will be a 6,000-seat ballpark on the Mitchel Field athletic complex at the edge of the redevelopment site. More review needs to be done before construction begins, but Mr. Boulton has already signed up to put an Atlantic League team there.
 ''We didn't want to have baseball just for the sake of having baseball,'' Scott Rechler, the chief executive of Reckson Associates, said in a recent interview. ''We wanted to have baseball in a family-entertainment sort of way.''
 The Meadowlands Xanadu development is no less ambitious. Besides a luxury hotel and office buildings, the Mills Corporation, the lead developer of the site, has vowed that Xanadu will be a 4.8-million-square-foot ''entertainment destination.''
 What Bergen County stands to gain -- if a ballpark is ever built there -- is a team that it truly can call its own.
 ''It's a community builder, it's something that can bring pride to a community,'' said Steve Cohen, the general manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones. ''We realize that not everyone who comes to a Cyclones game is a die-hard baseball fan.''
 As Mr. Cohen put it: ''For every two people who, walking in, are baseball fans, there are two people who aren't. But they leave with a smile on their faces, just like the baseball fans do.''

Leagues of Their Own
 When it comes to minor league baseball, it's hard to tell the teams in the region apart without a scorecard.
 Today, along with Long Island's one minor league team, there are two in New York City, one in Dutchess County upstate, four in Connecticut and eight in New Jersey, representing five leagues. Three of those leagues -- the Eastern, South Atlantic and New York-Penn Leagues -- consist of farm teams of major league clubs.
 The Eastern League is a Class AA league, meaning that its players are two steps from the majors, and the South Atlantic League is Class A, three steps away. Teams in each league play a 140-game season that opened earlier this month. 
 The New York-Penn League is a short-season Class A league, and its teams -- made up largely of players who tend to be younger and less skillful than in a long-season Class A league -- play a 76-game schedule beginning in June. 
 In addition, two independent leagues, the Atlantic and the Can-Am, have teams in the area. Neither has ties to the majors, but big-league clubs often raid independent teams to acquire players. 
 Of the two leagues, the Atlantic, which plays a 136-game schedule that opens this week, tends to have players who have accomplished more as professionals. The Long Island Ducks belong to the Atlantic League.
 The most notable Atlantic League player in recent years was Rickey Henderson, the former Yankees and Mets outfielder and the major league career leader in stolen bases, who played for the Newark Bears in 2003 before signing a contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers midway through the major league season. 
 The Can-Am League, which plays a 92-game schedule that begins in late May, features younger players who hope to impress scouts from major league teams looking to fill the rosters of their farm teams. 
 DAVE CALDWELL

HEADLINE: Trans-Atlantic Traffic Lanes Are Getting Busy

BYLINE: By Michelle Higgins

 BODY:
As the peak European travel season approaches, a number of major airlines are adding flights across the Atlantic. 
 Next month, Continental Airlines plans new flights from Newark to Cologne, Germany; Barcelona; and Copenhagen (above), bringing the total of European cities it flies to from Newark to 26. It is also adding flights on existing Newark routes, including to Edinburgh and Glasgow, and Manchester, England. 
With new service from Atlanta to Dusseldorf, Copenhagen, Athens and Edinburgh, among others, by summer, Delta will have more than 50 flights daily to 26 European cities. This summer, Lufthansa plans 227 flights a week from the United States to Germany, site of the World Cup, up from 214 last year. 
 Though the number of British Airways flights is only up slightly from last year, it is using bigger planes on certain European routes. On its three daily flights from Boston to London, for example, it is replacing Boeing 777's with 747's, raising capacity about 8 percent. 
 In all, the number of departures to Europe for June, July and August is rising about 7 percent to 35,223, according to Back Aviation Solutions, an industry-consulting firm, with Delta offering more than any other carrier. The number of seats to Europe is up 5.7 percent. 
 Despite the added capacity, fares are higher than last year. The average roundtrip economy fare from the United States to Europe booked in early April for summer travel was $898, up from $882 in the same period last year, according to Harrell Associates, an air-fare analysis firm. And with demand high, don't count on a major price drop.

LENGTH: 1050 words

HEADLINE: Worried About Noisy Children, and Hedge Funds, Too

BYLINE: By BEN STEIN. 
Ben Stein is a lawyer, writer, actor and economist. E-mail: ebiz@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FOR my sins, I travel constantly. I enjoy it most of the time, except for going through security lines, which is always hell. But I have come to notice a few new travel horrors that I feel duty-bound to share.
 First, because of the spread of mass prosperity or the accumulation of frequent-flier miles, more and more families with small children are flying in first class. (Don't bother writing to tell me that I am a bad person because I like to fly in first class. I have done my time in coach.) These small children often cry, to their parents' indifference, or, if the children are a bit older, have to be read to and played with at loud volume for five or six hours at a time. Nicht gut.
Second, and again because of the mass prosperity of Bush America (and don't bother telling me I am a creep because I like President Bush and think he's done a great job with the economy -- we do have a great economy, after all), there seem to be renovations in progress at every hotel where I stay. For reasons of sheer idiocy, construction seems to start at daybreak. This is insanely inconsiderate to us as guests, and I recommend long prison sentences for anyone involved. 
 Anyway, as I say, I travel a lot and I keep seeing men and women who are plumb worn out from hard work, early-morning flights, long days on the road and the burden of the BlackBerry, which, though it weighs just a few ounces, is as heavy as a cinder block in terms of how much it burdens its owner with responsibility while on the road. It endlessly occurs to me that I hope the teenage children of these men and women appreciate how hard their parents struggle to keep them in BMW's and whale belts. To me, traveling business executives are among the least-appreciated specimens on the planet, mostly by their own families. I just want you to know, Mr. and Ms. Traveler, that while the airlines don't care if you live or die (and neither does your teenager), I feel your pain. You see, I have a teenage son. 
 Well, this is all a digression. What I really wanted to say was that hedge funds are largely, but not always, a snare and a delusion. Hedge funds -- so called originally because they can hedge, or sell short -- started like gangbusters in the 1960's, died off, then came back with a rush when the tech bubble burst. They came back because they could make money by selling the technology stocks as they collapsed. In those days of ashes for Silicon Valley, hedge funds manufactured money.
 But the long-term record of most hedge funds is not at all impressive. Research by Burton G. Malkiel, a professor at Princeton, and Atanu Saha, a principal at the Analysis Group, found that over long periods hedge funds significantly underperform index funds, like those based on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. 
 For openers, the hedge funds they looked at -- starting with 604 in 1996 and rising to 2,700 in 2003 as the funds proliferated -- earned less than an S.& P. index fund in the period he studied, 1996 to 2003: an annual average return of 9.3 percent, compared with 9.4 percent for the index fund (and 10.1 percent for a simple stock-and-bond portfolio). But hedge funds also create much more tax liability because they trade so often and have so much short-term taxable income, compared with a tax-efficient index fund. And, as is well documented, they have far higher fees than index funds. 
 It is easy to buy an index fund that charges a management fee of only about 20 basis points -- two-tenths of a percentage point -- of the amount invested. A hedge fund takes an astounding fee of one to two full percentage points of net assets off the top, and then 20 percent of any profits. This cuts hedge fund returns to significantly less than those of broad-based index funds. 
 Dr. Malkiel and Dr. Saha calculated that even if hedge funds earned almost 50 percent more than market returns, the higher taxes and fees that hedge funds pay would whittle away their net return to investors to 20 percent less than index funds.
 Other commentators, including my pal and colleague, Phil DeMuth, say that even these results overstate hedge fund results. For one thing, there is survivorship bias -- always a problem in the back alleys of finance -- because only the hedge funds that survive report at all. If you take into account the ones that fail, the results would be worse. 
 Then there are problems of self-selection, in which only the funds that feel like it report at all, and instant-history bias, in which hedge funds that are brand new and have just had one good spurt can skew all the results. And because many assets of hedge funds are illiquid, the managers can put any price they want on them for any period until they sell them (and maybe even after that). This can be used to greatly underreport volatility because the assets in question can be reported at any price the managers wish, even while comparable liquid assets are gyrating wildly.
 To be sure, some hedge funds do well. Some do incredibly well, but rarely do any of them do incredibly well for a long time. As far as I can tell, in the past few years, almost none have done as well as the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index fund, the Dimensional Fund Advisors' U.S. Micro Cap Portfolio, Dimensional's Emerging Markets Portfolio or the wildly popular Fidelity Contrafund, all of which cost almost nothing to invest in -- although the Contrafund is being closed to new investors at the end of the month, and its glory days may have passed in any event).
 HEDGE funds, as Phil DeMuth says, are not necessarily a great investment, but they are a great compensation program for hedge fund managers. Warren Buffett, a true god of investments, says much the same thing eloquently in his most recent annual report for Berkshire Hathaway. His estimates of how much of America's corporate profits are sucked out of the system's owners, the shareholders, and diverted to investment managers is breathtaking and depressing.
 So, weary travelers, worry about bad hotels. Worry about parents who will not do a thing to quiet noisy children. And worry about the sad fact that your teenagers probably don't appreciate you. (Have I mentioned this already? I wonder why.) But don't feel bad if you're not in a hot hedge fund. Hardly anyone else is, either.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk; ECONOMIC VIEW; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1078 words

HEADLINE: Are Rich Politicians Selfless Politicians?

BYLINE: By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
CONSIDERING the nation's muddled campaign finance system, it's hardly a surprise that voters have taken a shine to a few wealthy entrepreneurs. There is an abiding American respect for people who build and manage big businesses, and rich politicians can also claim to avoid conflicts of interest by financing their own campaigns. But does experience back them up?
 The question is worth considering, said Amitai Etzioni, a professor at George Washington University, given the millions of dollars that candidates raise, even for relatively minor Congressional races. 
''If you are not affluent yourself, then you have to raise that money, and you spend a lot of time on courting people who have deep pockets and then attending to their special interests,'' Professor Etzioni said. ''Those with deep pockets at least can act virtuously if they wanted to. The others can't, because they have to be paying off special interests.''
 That feeling helped to elect billionaires like Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor of New York; Silvio Berlusconi, the prime minister of Italy who last week was contesting an apparent defeat at the polls; and Thaksin Shinawatra, who resigned as prime minister of Thailand this month. Yet some recent research suggests that while wealthy businesspeople in politics may not cater much to others, the markets certainly expect them to take care of their own private interests.
 Mara Faccio, an assistant professor of management at Vanderbilt University, looked at the cases of 109 capitalists and entrepreneurs who were elected to political office in 47 countries. She chose politicians in two categories: those who owned at least 10 percent of the shares of a publicly traded company (which many economists consider a controlling interest), and those who had been chief executive, president or vice president of such a company.
 In a paper published in March in The American Economic Review, Ms. Faccio reported that the politicians' companies experienced a 2.3 percent increase in their share prices, on average, around the time of their electoral victories. If a politician entered the executive branch of government, the effect was larger -- up to a 12 percent lift for companies associated with new presidents, prime ministers and other top officials. 
 ''The results suggest that the politician is acting in the interest of the company,'' Ms. Faccio said in an interview by telephone. ''And the effects were much larger in countries with high corruption.''
 In another twist, Ms. Faccio found that when a politician's company was part of a larger business group where he yielded significant voting control, the share prices of the other companies in the group often fell at the time of his victory. ''The value of companies he controls directly goes up, but the value of other companies in the group tends to go down,'' she said. As a reason, Ms. Faccio suggested that a politician might work to benefit his own company, while leaning on the rest of the business group to supply services to his campaign.
 In the United States, it may take a lot of wealth to buy you independence. According to financial disclosures, about half of senators are millionaires, said Chellie Pingree, president and chief executive of Common Cause, the ethics watchdog group. But virtually all of those senators still raise money for their campaigns rather than paying their own way.
 Ms. Pingree herself ran for the Senate as a Democrat in Maine, losing to the Republican incumbent, Susan M. Collins, in 2002. ''You're spending the majority of your time raising money, so you're either on the telephone all the time like a telemarketer or you're at events,'' Ms. Pingree said. To avoid the fund-raising entirely, ''you practically have to be a billionaire.''
 The experience of legislators running companies may be overrated as well, Ms. Pingree said. ''You take somebody like Bill Frist, whose family made millions and millions of dollars with HCA, the hospital company,'' she said. ''Has he been able to use those skills to reform the health care system? Do we have less of a budget deficit because he's leading the Senate?''
 She added, however, that executive experience might be more important for a mayor, governor or president. ''You could argue that there are times when the skills that make you a better executive in those positions,'' she said, ''are the skills that come from having started or run a business, because it is different -- you're the boss.''
 Professor Etzioni disagreed. ''Politics is really not about good management,'' he said. ''Politics is about taking conflicting interests, conflicting values and building common ground.'' To set the agenda is the right job for politicians, he said, ''not to make the railroads run on time.''
 Despite these misgivings, Professor Etzioni said he would prefer to see a crop of wealthy, self-financed candidates rather than relying on the current system. ''If I cannot get my first-best, public financing, that would be my second-best,'' he said. ''It's not good, but it's a lot better.'' In the current system, he added, ''it's no longer the lobbyists pressuring the congressmen, but the congressmen who solicit for money and favors.''
 Requiring candidates to finance their own campaigns might lead to more accusations that wealthy politicians are buying elections with bombardments of television ads, salvos of direct mailings and an army of well-paid, well-organized troops on the ground. Yet that perception, too, may be wrong. Jeff D. Milyo, an associate professor of economics at the University of Missouri, studied whether wealthier candidates in the House had an electoral edge, with results adjusted for their party's overall advantage and the competitiveness of the district. He found no statistically significant effect.
 BUT in more recent work, Mr. Milyo discovered that riches also made little difference in voting records. ''Even a change as large as a million dollars in wealth one way or another makes almost no difference in the observed interest group ratings,'' he said. ''It's completely swamped by party, the leanings of the district and tenure.''
 So are wealthier politicians really more independent? It's not easy to generalize, even among the relatively small number of billionaires in politics. The direction of Ms. Faccio's research, though, was motivated by one billionaire in particular.
 ''I really dislike Silvio Berlusconi,'' she said. ''It's personal. I'm Ital-ian.''

SECTION: Section 6; Column 3; Magazine; THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 4-23-06; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: Export This?

BYLINE: By Jim Holt. 
Jim Holt is a frequent contributor to the magazine.

 BODY:
Democracy is a wonderful thing. We Americans have been enjoying it for over two centuries. Gradually, fitfully, much of the rest of the world has joined us. Although competing systems may menace it for a time, they will eventually collapse because of their internal contradictions. That is why the advance of democracy is inevitable. And the best the United States can do is to help history along by pushing it on recalcitrant parts of the world, like the Middle East.
But wait. Are we sure that what we are enjoying and promoting is democracy? True, we call it that. But the regimes of the former Soviet bloc also called themselves democracies. Suppose their system had won out -- a possibility that may be hard to imagine now but that was once a source of anxiety in the West. They, too, would have proclaimed a triumph of democracy. But surely, you want to say, their democratic pretensions were ludicrous. When Kim Jong Il refers to his nation as the ''Democratic People's Republic of Korea,'' it sounds like a case of a double positive yielding a negative. Our claim to be a democracy, by contrast, is fully merited. Just like the Greeks who, two and a half millennia ago, both coined the term and invented the thing, we have government by the people. 
 There are two problems with this line of thought. The first is that our form of government bears scant resemblance to what the ancients called demokratia. Tellingly, we hardly recognize the name of its inventor, Kleisthenes. The most distinctive feature of Athenian democracy, as the British political theorist John Dunn reminds us in his forthcoming book, ''Democracy: A History,'' was its ''fierce directness.'' Laws were made by an assembly that every full citizen had the right to attend, address and vote in as an equal. (Excluding women, resident aliens and slaves, that left about 30,000 participants.) The assembly's agenda for each meeting was decided on by a council of 500 citizens, chosen by lot. The only elected figures were military generals, and this was considered the least democratic aspect of the system.
 Our own government, to the Athenians, would look like an elective oligarchy. In fact, it was deliberately set up to ensure, as James Madison wrote in the Federalist Papers, ''the total exclusion of the people in their collective capacity, from any share'' in it. Yet we insist on applying a Greek label to it as an honorific. And that is the second problem. For most of history, ''democracy'' was a term of abuse, connoting the rule of the vulgar multitude. The founding fathers fought shy of it, taking care to use ''republic'' instead.
 Today, democracy is what has been called an ''essentially contested concept.'' We project our various pet values onto it, and then are puzzled that it cannot consistently hold them all. Francis Fukuyama, who has argued that democracy is ''the end point of mankind's ideological evolution,'' refuses to admit the Athenian demos to the club, on the grounds that it failed to protect human rights -- notably, the right of its most famous citizen, Socrates, to corrupt the young and invent his own gods. Others are similarly loath to extend the rubric of democracy to present-day Iran, where elections are held under the supervision of a priestly caste, or to the Palestinian entity, on the grounds that the newly elected Hamas government is a terrorist organization.
 The United States is governed neither by priests nor by terrorists (notwithstanding some overheated rhetoric to that effect) but by professional politicians -- or ''electoral entrepreneurs,'' as the economist Joseph Schumpeter called them -- who compete for our votes. They are said to represent us, but representation is as vexed a notion as democracy itself. Clearly, politicians do not represent us in the sense of being like us: quite apart from some peculiar psychological characteristics common to the breed, they are older, maler, whiter and lawyers almost to a man. Ideally, though, they represent us in the sense of looking after our interests, the way a guardian represents an infant in law. Unlike an infant, we have an intermittent right to replace them with other politicians if we judge them to be ineffective in this representative role. But, owing to a byzantine division of labor, much of what politicians do is hidden away from the public eye. Moreover, in one of the more devastating theoretical arguments against democracy, Anthony Downs observed that most citizens have no economic incentive to learn enough about what politicians do to vote intelligently. Nearly half of American voters acquiesce in their infantilization by not voting at all.
 Should any of this make us yearn for Athenian-style demokratia, where citizens come together on terms of equality to reach consensus about the common good? An innovation in this direction has been proposed by James Fishkin, a political scientist at Stanford, and Bruce Ackerman, a Yale law professor. They envisage a new national holiday, called ''Deliberation Day,'' a couple of weeks before each major election. On this day, voters would gather in groups as large as 500 and hash out issues together, like the ancient Athenians. (Unlike the Athenians, participants in Deliberation Day would be paid $150 each.) If this sort of thing sounds appealing, keep in mind that the right to address your fellow citizens is accompanied by the less agreeable duty to heed what they have to say, and that means all of them.
 If nothing else, the system we sloppily call democracy provides a way to get rid of a lousy regime without the bother of overthrowing it by force. As for its apparent historic inevitability, that may owe largely to the difficulty of finding any other source of legitimacy besides ''the people.'' ''Virtue''? That went out with Plato. ''Embodying the national spirit'' became unfashionable with Hitler, as did ''expressing the will of the proletariat'' with Stalin. True, some rulers continue to imagine that they were chosen by God. But almost no one takes that idea seriously anymore.

LENGTH: 887 words

HEADLINE: Inviting New Business To the Old World

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN. 
William J. Holstein is editor in chief of Chief Executive magazine.

 BODY:
JOHN BRUTON, the European Union's ambassador to the United States and the former Irish prime minister, says American chief executives are mistaken if they believe that Western Europe is slow-growing or protectionist. Here are excerpts from a conversation:

Q. Are you concerned that we're seeing more protectionism, or even economic nationalism, on both sides of the Atlantic?

A. In Europe last year, there were more takeovers by companies of one country of companies in another country than in any year since 2000. So it's not surprising that there has been the occasional case in which questions have been raised. But if you were to look at Europe 10 years ago, many companies wouldn't have even contemplated making the offers they are today. You could argue that the controversy is a sign of liberalization, rather than the opposite. 
 There is, in every country, a wariness about foreign ownership. But a study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development shows that the foreign investment laws in nine countries of the European Union are more liberal than are the laws in the United States of America.

Q. What was European reaction to the furor that prevented a Dubai group from buying control of ports in the United States from a British company?

A. There was a worry that the issue was being looked at not on its actual merit or on genuine security grounds, but rather on broader political grounds. In Europe, we do not feel that political barriers should be put in the way of investments. To have a stevedoring operating entity owned by one foreign company being taken over by another foreign company wouldn't have prejudiced the right of the U.S. Coast Guard or Customs to do all they needed to do to protect security. I have spent time talking to members of Congress about this. Europe is by far the biggest investor in the United States. America should remain a place that welcomes foreign investment. I was reassured. Members said this was a unique case and didn't have broader implications.

Q. How much has Europe invested in the United States?

A. European companies have more money invested in the state of Texas alone than the United States has invested in China and Japan combined. European investment in the United States is by far the largest from any external source. Some 14 million jobs on both sides of the Atlantic are dependent on foreign investment.

Q. Why aren't American executives more interested in investing in Western Europe?

A. They haven't really understood the magnitude of the reforms. France has dramatically reformed as a result of the 35-hour week being changed. The amount that companies must pay in overtime is less than in the United States. And France is spending about 10 percent of its gross domestic product on health care, compared with the United States, which is spending 16 percent. France has one of the best health care systems in the world. It also has undergone major pension reform, raising the average retirement age by two years.
 And in Germany, there has been a major reform of the labor market. Businesses now pay reduced long-term unemployment benefits. In the Netherlands, there's been a major overhaul of disability law.

Q. Why are investors bypassing Western Europe for Eastern and Central Europe?

A. If the European Union had not expanded or had refused to take in those 10 new countries, I don't think American companies would be looking at them. When we take in new member states, we are giving them a guarantee that their citizens can work anywhere in the European Union. Romanian construction workers will be free to work in Britain. There may be some delays and transition periods. But there is a revolution taking place in the European labor market. It's equivalent to what would happen if the United States and Mexico were to merge. In Europe, this isn't just an idea. In Europe, this is actually happening.

Q. Aren't some American companies having trouble in Western Europe -- like Hewlett-Packard, which ran into resistance from the French government over plans to downsize its operations in Grenoble, or Microsoft?

A. Microsoft is having trouble because it is an accused monopolist. The European Union is not afraid to take on monopolists or would-be monopolists.

Q. Have trans-Atlantic economic wounds over the war in Iraq begun healing?

A. There was never any impact on trade and never any impact on investment and reinvestment. In the trans-Atlantic relationship, people are free to disagree. In fairness to President Bush, he has gone out of his way to be cognizant of Europe and the European Union. His visit to the commission, a year ago, was the first ever by an American president. Since then, he has been strong in his insistence on consultation with the European Union. We are cooperating on Syria and Lebanon. We're cooperating in regard to Iran, which is extremely difficult. We also are cooperating on China and the alleged piracy of intellectual property.

Q. But in economic terms, hasn't something changed?

A. In 2004, the United States invested $7 billion in France, almost double what the U.S. invested in China. European companies have accounted for 75 percent of foreign investment in the United States over the past five years. American companies earn more from their investments in Europe than from the rest of the world combined.

HEADLINE: The Not-So United States

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

 BODY:
AFTER Massachusetts became the first state to enact near-universal health care coverage this month, Robert E. Travaglini, the State Senate president, allowed himself a bit of bravado. 
 ''This is going to be a template for the rest of the nation to follow, and not just this,'' Mr. Travaglini crowed, rattling off a list of recent Massachusetts milestones. ''We did this for same-sex marriage; we did this for stem cell research. Massachusetts is at the head of the curve.''
Ahead of the curve for some, perhaps. But for those sitting in, say, South Dakota, which recently enacted a law that bans all abortions except those necessary to save the life of the mother, Massachusetts might look more like it has gone off the deep end. And vice versa. 
 Such are the political and ideological extremes bubbling up from the states these days. Local legislatures are debating everything from teaching ''intelligent design'' as an alternative to evolution in public schools to financing stem cell research to preventing gay couples from adopting. 
 These debates raise a number of questions. Is the country destined to balkanize into a patchwork of polar-opposite policies? How will this diversity be reconciled? Does it need to be? 
 There have been other points in American history when state laws were radically different, historians say, citing slavery, and then the Jim Crow laws in the South. This could be another time of radical divergence.
 ''I think this is up there among the eras of greatest distance among the states,'' said John D. Donahue, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. ''It's because we have fairly intense cleavages in values, preferences, points of view among the population, and in some of these areas they do tend to cluster state by state.''
 Consider California, where a bill introduced in the Legislature this month would make the state the first to impose limits on the emissions of all greenhouse gases. Also, California, along with New Jersey, Maryland and Connecticut, has allocated money for stem cell research. 
 And Rhode Island passed a law this year allowing the use of medical marijuana despite the fact that the Supreme Court ruled last June that the authorities could prosecute users of marijuana even when the state allows its use.
 On the other end of the political spectrum are states like Idaho, Georgia and 17 others with constitutional amendments banning same-sex marriage. Or Florida, Mississippi and Utah, which effectively ban adoption by same-sex couples.
 In some ways this landscape is a blue state-red state divide, but it goes beyond cultural hot buttons to issues like health care and tort reform. It raises the specter of people migrating to different states because of their policies. Will people move to Kansas, for example, because they want schools that include a critical approach to evolution in their curriculum? Because same-sex marriage is currently not an option for anyone other than Massachusetts residents or people who intend to reside there, some same-sex couples have established Massachusetts residency so they can marry. 
 Certainly, the emergence of strong state stances on social issues like same-sex marriage and abortion reflects a certain amount of political strategy and opportunism. 
 Political parties ''have seen the advantages of cultural wedge issues and seek to inflame them,'' Professor Donahue said. ''We haven't had a rip-roaring depression for awhile and when economic issues seem less urgent, there is more room for secondary issues to become political motivators.'' 
 The federal government's posture on certain issues also spurs action by the states. On some issues, the federal government, under the current and other recent administrations, has imposed far-reaching laws and regulations, said John Kincaid, a professor of government and public service at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa.
 ''There's been a tremendous amount of federal pre-emption of state law in last couple of decades,'' Dr. Kincaid said. He cited federal laws governing consumers, food labeling, class-action lawsuits and the No Child Left Behind education law.
 ''So the states are responding,'' he said. ''I think we've moved from an era of cooperative federalism to an era of coercive federalism in which the federal government is really dictating to the states. That has produced a really activist response of states trying to cope with this.''
 On the other hand, some states appear to feel that the federal government has not done enough on some issues. ''Look what states are doing on global warming,'' said Alan Ehrenhalt, executive editor of Governing magazine. ''Many of them are involved in climate change and that may well force the federal government's hand. Stem cell research -- states are doing that because the Bush administration doesn't want to do very much.''
 This atmosphere has turned the concept of federalism, once a favorite of conservatives seizing on states' rights to buck liberal national laws and court decisions, into an equal-opportunity idea embraced just as readily by liberals -- especially with a White House and Congress dominated by Republicans. 
 That is what Richard Thompson Ford, a Stanford University law professor, argued in an article posted on Slate.com last year. 
 ''Many liberals who haven't yet moved to Canada have indulged the fantasy of a 'blue state' secessionist movement,'' he wrote. ''But the American legal tradition does offer liberals a practical alternative to secession or a condo in Vancouver. It's called federalism, a k a 'state's rights.' Liberals often have a reflexive distaste for decentralization of political power: State and local autonomy strike them as provincial and regressive. But much of the association of federalism with conservative politics is the result of historical accident: There is nothing inherently conservative about limitations on the power of Congress and the executive.'' 
 SIMILAR cycles of divergence have occurred at other times in American history, historians and political scientists said. 
 ''Is it any more extreme than having slavery in Virginia and laws excluding blacks from voting in Illinois when they could in Maine?'' asked Pauline Maier, a professor of American history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''Not all states march in sync. There's always been a patch-quilt of state institutions and I think it's a fine thing. You can get so much creative legislation. In fact, the variety of state polices has been in many ways a strength to the states. In many ways, states showed a better way of dealing with things and a more just society. In other states, they may have seemed backward for a time, but at least they were isolated.''
 Mr. Ehrenhalt said periods of state assertiveness come ''in cycles and it depends on who's in power in Washington and who's in power in the states.''
 The early-20th century was another time of state activism, historians said. Ultimately, ''much of the New Deal legislation in the 1930's was modeled after state legislation,'' Dr. Kincaid said. In the years before the New Deal, he said, ''a lot of states had old-age pensions that looked a lot like Social Security and workmen's compensation.''
 The crystal ball, then, would indicate that some of the issues enthralling the states will eventually get sorted out nationally in federal legislation. Mr. Ehrenhalt said a ''national standard'' develops that ''tends to be less rigorous than the most extreme state, but farther along than states that haven't done anything yet.'' 
 But don't expect that to happen overnight, or on every issue. Dr. Kincaid predicts ''a significant buildup of policy actions in the states that will get reflected in the Congressional elections'' and over time, lead to federal change. Other issues, like abortion, reside with the federal courts, meaning actions like South Dakota's could have no impact on the outcome. 
 ''There are some things where state diversity works out just fine,'' Professor Donahue. ''When Montana doesn't have any daytime speed limits the effects are fairly minor because Montana has a lot of wide open spaces and it doesn't affect another state. But there are other things, like air pollution, where what one state does makes a difference. On the smaller issues it's O.K. to have differences. On the biggies you have spillover.'' 
 Give it a decade before the spillover gets sorted out, Professor Donahue said. ''If you look through American history there's an ebb and flow of more state autonomy and more federal authority,'' he said. ''Within another 10 years we're going to see another season of centralization and I think we'll have convergence on a lot of issues.''

HEADLINE: Once Marginal, But Now Kings Of the Oil World

BYLINE: By JAD MOUAWAD

 BODY:
OIL futures settled above $75 a barrel last week, and analysts blamed the usual cocktail of geopolitics and domestic instability. There was Iran's challenge to the West over its nuclear research program, as well as the seemingly endless conflicts within Nigeria and Iraq. All those countries are major oil exporters, producing some eight million barrels a day. 
 Now, add Chad's problems to the mix. 
Idriss Deby, Chad's president, threatened to shut off the country's production of 180,000 barrels of oil a day by May if Exxon Mobil and other oil companies don't pay $100 million in new oil taxes. The threat was the latest in Chad's attempts to get the World Bank to loosen an agreement that limits how much oil money the graft-ridden government can spend. 
 Chad, which has been producing oil since 2003, isn't a big player on the oil market. And in the not-too-distant past, what happened in Chad was of little consequence to oil traders, analysts or, for that matter, drivers pulling up at the pump. Similarly, the fate of Sudan or Yemen, Azerbaijan or the Congo Republic (the smaller of two countries named Congo), didn't matter much to the balance of global petroleum supplies. There was enough oil sloshing around to make up for any shortfall, anywhere.
 That's no longer the case. In a world where every single barrel counts, the actions of Chad's president could threaten global energy security.
 The world currently consumes a little over 85 million barrels of oil a day. Producers can meet this demand, but little is left over. Only Saudi Arabia possesses an additional 1.5 million barrels of untapped capacity to make up for any interruptions.
 Because the world is pumping at just about full capacity, the global oil market cannot afford the loss of exports from even the smallest producer. And now, even the marginal producer can influence oil prices. Some have realized they have disproportionate clout in the markets and on the geopolitical stage.
 Ecuador, for example, wants a larger share of revenue from foreign oil companies and recently approved a new hydrocarbon law that amounts to a unilateral breach of production contracts. The government itself is under pressure from provincial leaders who are demanding a greater share of the country's oil wealth. 
 Add to that the local industry's frequent strikes -- four, so far this year -- and the investment climate in Ecuador becomes bleak. Last year, a strike interrupted Ecuador's oil exports for two weeks and contributed to a $2-per-barrel jump in the price of oil futures traded in New York, according to Eurasia Group, a political-risk consultancy in New York.
 ''Today's exceptionally tight market gives marginal producers unprecedented power and greater geopolitical importance,'' said Ian Bremmer, the president of Eurasia Group, which specializes in assessing how politics affect oil markets. ''They have the ability to press. They have leverage.''
 According to Eurasia Group, 12 small producers are currently facing heightened levels of political risk, which eventually might curtail their domestic oil production or foreign investment. Taken together, these countries account for over 4.6 million barrels a day of production, 5 percent of the world's total, or more than the output of any single OPEC nation except Saudi Arabia.
 Of course, some of the world's biggest producers have also been facing turmoil. Nigeria, Africa's top producer, has been forced to curb its output by 500,000 barrels a day, or about 20 percent of the country's usual total, because of violence in the Niger Delta since the beginning of the year. 
 Iraq, which pumped 2.5 million barrels a day before the war, is now able to produce barely half that amount. 
 In Venezuela, President Hugo Chavez, encouraged by the high prices, has tried to raise sharply the taxes and royalties on foreign oil companies. That stance has led to much uncertainty about the future of foreign investment there. Saudi Arabia recently foiled an attempt to blow up the country's largest oil-processing plant, a reminder that the kingdom is still vulnerable to terrorism.
 ''Risk is a big category,'' said Alan Hegburg, a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. ''And there's all kinds of risks. But the United States, just like everyone else, is exposed. For example, we're exposed to a major shutdown in oil production in Nigeria, or a major disaster in Saudi Arabia's oil industry.''
 Eventually, production will increase, demand might slow, and the importance of marginal producers will wane. Then, oil analysts will have to worry only about the long term stability of places like Saudi Arabia, Nigeria or Iraq.
 Meanwhile, they need to remember that even the Congo Republic matters.

HEADLINE: What's That Label? Why, It's a Mongo

BYLINE: By ANDREW ADAM NEWMAN

 BODY:
LAURI APPLE was walking along East Seventh Street near Tompkins Square Park on a recent Sunday afternoon when the white plastic bag on the curb beckoned. She paused and -- to no one in particular -- said, ''There are clothes in there.''
 The bag, tied and completely closed, seemed just as likely to contain foam peanuts or medical waste.
But a moment later, Ms. Apple was extracting women's clothing, including a light green wool-blend Forever 21 sweater (good condition), a short-sleeved Ann Taylor white knit shirt (stained), and a black Victoria's Secret something-or-other with attached pink belt (inexplicable). Ms. Apple dropped the sweater into her shoulder bag, returned the other items and soldiered on. 
 Wait. How did she know there were clothes in the bag? 
 ''I don't know,'' she said. ''I just had this feeling.''
 That bordering-on-clairvoyance feeling came a decade ago to Ms. Apple, 30, a law student who lives in Astoria, Queens, when she began acquiring lost and discarded clothes. The draw is equal parts thrill of the hunt, political response to a throwaway culture and frugality. ''My family has had encounters with poverty,'' said Ms. Apple, who grew up in Johnstown, Pa. When she was 5 her father was laid off by United States Steel and remained jobless for two and a half years. During her 20's, she joined antiglobalization activists protesting the World Bank and encountered freegans -- Dumpster-diving anticonsumerists who aspire to buy nothing. 
 Less rebellious today, she considers herself a civil libertarian and a conservative in the literal sense: she conserves. ''I've always been a little bit fringy,'' Ms. Apple said, her eyes panning the sidewalk as she walked and then stooped to pick up a penny. ''My lifestyle doesn't make sense to some people -- including me sometimes.'' 
 So Ms. Apple was not entirely optimistic when a couple of months ago she turned to the Internet in search of fellow travelers. She discovered myriad Web sites dedicated either to letters and photographs found on the street -- Found Magazine being the most prominent -- or clothes purchased used. But when Ms. Apple trawled for sites dedicated exclusively to finding clothes, the Net came up empty. So recently she started her own, Foundclothing (foundclothing.blogspot.com), where she posts photos of her bounty, lists where and when items were found and occasionally adds personal notes. Her collection spans various cities where she has lived and includes simple knit shirts, chic but prohibitively uncomfortable shoes and a BCBG Max Azria dress (near Prospect Park in Brooklyn, December 2004) that she slips on for job interviews and fancy parties. 
 Visitors are encouraged to post photos of their own finds. (The site has been up about a month, and no one has yet.) Ms. Apple wants those who witness her rooting through garbage to stop giving her the hairy eyeball. Her stated mission: ''To take away the stigma associated with found clothes and also to celebrate these items as free, reused fashions.''
 But can Ms. Apple win over the germ phobic masses? 
 Garbage picking ''requires a capacity to deal with looks that can be more severe than the smells,'' Ted Botha wrote in his 2004 book, ''Mongo: Adventures in Trash,'' which follows collectors who comb trash for everything from rare books to computers to food. (''Mongo'' gained currency in New York in the 1980's as slang for valuables found in the garbage.) 
 While Mr. Botha's wardrobe includes found items, he has never encountered someone dedicated solely to finding clothing. Visitors to GarbageScout.com, started in January by Jim Nachlin, are encouraged to use cellphone cameras to post and view recently spied (and computer-mapped) curbside goodies. No one has posted clothing yet, Mr. Nachlin said. 
 ''Most people are put off by the idea of used clothing,'' said Al Hoff, thrift store maven and author of ''Thrift Score.'' She (Al is short for Alison) views upscale consignment shops as ''gateway drugs'' to the previously off-put. ''Once they get used to wearing someone else's clothing, they get more liberal about it'' and will go to the Salvation Army and even the way of Ms. Apple, she said. ''What's the difference if you buy a used shirt from a high-end consignment store or you find it at the Port Authority?'' Ms. Hoff asked. ''It's the same thing.''
 Still, everyone has limits. ''A lot of people who buy used clothing draw the line at underwear,'' Ms. Hoff said. ''It's a visceral reaction to clothing being next to that part of your body -- it's too intimate, like sitting on a warm toilet seat.''
 Too intimate for Ms. Apple, in fact. ''No underwear,'' she said. ''No. No. No. That's a bright-line rule, as lawyers say.'' Clothes she takes, meanwhile, undergo what she describes on her site as a ''patented found-and-boil technique: Take found clothing item, throw it in the sink, pour in a bunch of soap and then boil.'' The water, while not actually boiling, is as steamy as the tap gets.
 Jack Linard, a chemist with Unilever who formulates laundry detergents including All and Wisk, said that he personally ''would not have any hesitancy'' about wearing something found lightly soiled in the street -- after simply putting it through the wash. ''Body soils that come from a different person are what people really worry about,'' Mr. Linard said. ''And in warm or hot water you're going to get most of the body soils out, though not sanitize it.'' 
 Collectors could get in hot water themselves -- with the law. A New York City regulation prohibits anyone besides sanitation workers to ''disturb or remove ashes, garbage, refuse (including recycling) or rubbish'' on the curb. Violators face a fine of up to $300, but in an e-mail message Matthew LiPani, a New York City Sanitation Department spokesman, stated that as of the fiscal year 2005, only 14 people have ever been fined for that violation. 
 According to property law, ''abandoned'' property generally is fair game, though taking property someone can lay claim to is theft. Ms. Apple said that she only takes something if it ''looks lost, dropped or intentionally put out in the trash.''
 ''If there's a remote chance that the owner is around to claim it,'' she added, ''I don't stretch the rules.'' 
 Does that put her on solid legal ground?
 Ms. Apple, who is finishing her second year at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, shrugged, ''I got a C-plus in property law.''
 For all her scavenging, found clothes make up only about 15 percent of her wardrobe, though she is a dedicated thrift-store shopper as well. But she is hardly freegan and buys more than just socks and underwear new. ''When I get depressed, I like to go buy clothes,'' she said. Her favorite place to shop: Forever 21, with its inexpensive fashions for women hovering at or below the legal drinking age. ''I buy the stuff that's not trendy enough for the 21-year-olds,'' she said. 
 Still, for Ms. Apple clothes off the rack are less interesting than those off the street. ''If there's a philosophy behind this, it's to keep my memory in check,'' she said. ''These clothes are like tab markers for memories. They help me remember certain walks, or where I was living.''
 Imbued with such memories, some of her finds become almost too precious. There is a shirt that Ms. Apple found while she lived in Prague in 1996 that is translucent with silver threads, at once gauzy and bright, like memory itself. Nine years passed before she finally put it on last fall. ''I like it, but it just took me so long to wear it,'' she said. ''I just don't think I wanted anything to happen to it.''

HEADLINE: Adorned in Good Deeds 

BYLINE: By Ellen Tien

 BODY:
Last winter women accessorized blouses, blazers and bags with $525 boucle flower brooches by Chanel for a look-rich-quick effect. This spring young women can brighten up T-shirts, jean jackets and backpacks with handwoven flower pins made for the Estella children's boutique in New York (212-255-3553). The pins, in five colors, have a dusting of sequins and are an easy splurge at $15 each. The cotton baubles are made in conjunction with Citta, an organization that gives work to unemployed women in Nepal. The money they earn by making pins goes toward health care and education there, which means consumers can help enrich the lives of others, rather than just look rich.
