HEADLINE: Heading Off a Culture Clash 

BYLINE: By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: TOMS RIVER 

 BODY:
AS fine arts supervisor for this large Ocean County school district, Kim Defibaugh is scrambling to complete 21 different versions of an eight-page survey aimed at sizing up the art, music, theater and dance programs at her schools. 
 She is not alone.
 While school administrators and board of education candidates spent the last week fretting over the passage of budgets or getting elected, fine arts teachers at 2,408 schools throughout the state have had other concerns. The New Jersey Visual and Performing Arts Education Survey, begun earlier this month, is being described as the most comprehensive look at arts education ever done by a state.
 The online surveys, which were mandated by the State Department of Education, must be completed by the end of the month. They come at a time when districts face leaner budgets and there is a new emphasis on test scores in major subject areas. 
 In the detailed survey, arts instructors and administrators are being asked such things as the number of students enrolled in classes like sculpture, photography, ballet or choir; what portion of the school's overall budget is allocated to the arts; the number of classrooms dedicated to the arts; incentives for teachers to pursue professional development; if the school has an artist-in-residence program, and how often students attend performances or exhibitions outside of school. 
 The findings, which are expected to be made public in September, will gauge how well individual elementary, middle and high schools are adhering to a state mandate to provide a well-rounded arts education. As the first step in the broader Arts Education Census Project, the survey will also serve as the basis for identifying model arts programs and establishing a clearinghouse on arts education where schools can share ideas. 
 ''Many people believe arts are important, but nobody's actually measuring what's happening,'' said Robert Morrison, chairman of the Music for All Foundation, a national arts advocacy organization, based in Warren, that is spearheading the survey effort. ''We want to know who has access and who doesn't. Where are the robust programs that others can learn from?''
 Another goal is to determine how much truth there is to the anecdotal evidence that with the emphasis now being placed on test scores, arts education is suffering. Mr. Morrison questioned the long-range value of ''teaching to the test.''
 ''Is proficiency in reading and math enough? Is that what we want our children to be able to do?'' asked Mr. Morrison, who also served as the chief executive of VH1's Save the Music Foundation. ''We don't teach music to make great musicians, or art to become great artists. In an economy driven by innovation and ideas, the skill that is needed is creativity and the best way to develop creativity is through music and art.''
 Rather than punish schools that are not living up to recommended standards, the survey aims to identify gaps where help is needed, according to John Pietrowski, the artistic director of Playwrights Theater of New Jersey, another partner in the survey project.
 ''We understand the difficulties,'' Mr. Pietrowski said. ''Under No Child Left Behind and testing, often times arts programs are being short-shrifted.'' 
 Yet while the survey is not intended to punish districts that are providing mediocre arts education, it could, ironically, end up adversely affecting districts that are doing well. Arts funding organizations like the New Jersey State Council on the Arts and the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation are hoping the survey will help them determine if their grants are being properly channeled.
 ''When faced with limited resources, we need to know where we can have the most impact,'' said David Miller, executive director of the state Arts Council, which annually provides $23 million in art grants, with a heavy emphasis on education-oriented programs. ''The survey will allow us for many years to come to allocate our resources wisely.'' 
 The Dodge Foundation, which donated $80,000 for the art survey and is paying close to half the $300,000 cost of the Arts Education Census Project, gives more than $4 million annually to education programs in the state, with more than one-third of that being aimed specifically at arts education.
 ''We have an interest in knowing where the gaps are in arts programming so we can allocate our funding more effectively,'' said Ross Davis, education program director for the Dodge Foundation. ''We think there are pockets of schools that get all the funds just because they know how, and others that don't get any.''
 At the same time, Mr. Davis said the foundation is not interested in rewarding schools that are neglecting their responsibility to the arts. ''It's not our job to fill in the holes in areas you are responsible for,'' he said. ''We can't contribute to the dysfunction if a school decides its going to cut art and be out of compliance.''
 The visual and performing arts are one of the nine subject areas that have been mandated by the New Jersey's Core Content Curriculum Standards since 1996. The state's commitment to the arts was reinforced last year when the high school graduation requirements specified that students must have one year of fine-arts education. In the past, this requirement could be fulfilled with a practical arts course, like careers, or woodshop.
 The curriculum standards do not specify numbers of art classes, hours or instructors needed to fulfill the requirement, but rather emphasize the knowledge and skills students should have at various grade levels in the areas of art, music, theater and dance. 
 While nearly all schools have separate and defined art and music programs, typically theater instruction is folded into English courses, while dance is taught during physical education. Nevertheless, including these programs in the core curriculum indicates an unusual commitment to the arts, according to New Jersey's acting education commissioner, Lucille E. Davy.
 ''I don't know that across the country, everyone places that same value on the arts,'' Ms. Davy said.
 But at a time when the state is suffering from budgetary constraints, no additional funds are earmarked for education this year, even though New Jersey ranks among the lowest in the country in financing education, with 38 percent of school funds coming from the state. 
 Moreover, less than 3 percent of school financing comes from the federal government -- the lowest in the country -- and 59 percent comes from local property taxes. New Jersey is one of the few states where taxpayers get to vote on school budgets. 
 Throughout the state last week, school budgets were approved in only 52.1 percent of local school districts, the lowest level since 1994, when voters approved 51.4 percent of the school budgets.
 ''Voters are frustrated,'' said Mike Yaple, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association. ''They've seen state aid for school remain stagnant for five straight years. During that time, costs are going up and in some schools, arts are getting squeezed.''
 With a state-mandated 4-percent cap on increases in school budgets, some school districts chose to place arts-spending items in a second ballot question rather than include them in the overall school budget. Mr. Yaple said such maneuvering is dangerous, since second ballot questions have a higher failure rate and cannot be appealed. Only 33 percent of second ballot questions were approved this year.
 In Cherry Hill, a district that has long prided itself on its arts and theater programs, voters were asked to approve an $4additional million, on top of the district's $132 million budget, to retain 37 teaching positions, including 6 music teachers and 3 art teachers. With a muscular get-out-the-vote effort, the budget and the second ballot question both passed on Tuesday. In nearby Medford, voters rejected an additional $180,000 to go toward reading, math and band teachers in the middle school.
 If Cherry Hill's second ballot question had failed, the district's middle schools would have been left with no instrumental music program, and art classes would have been reduced to 30 minutes.
 ''There's a lot of emotion attached to the instrumental music program,'' said a district spokeswoman, Susan Bastnagel. ''It's been part of our culture for a long, long time. It's a shame it's had to come to this.''
 Most of the state's poorer school districts are designated as Abbott districts and receive about $4.1 billion in state aid as well as additional federal financing, allowing them to provide good arts programs. Likewise, many small wealthy districts try to emphasize on the arts.
 Frank Azzaro, the art supervisor at the Rumson-Fair Haven Regional High School, said the school's vast arts programming ''has always been a pride of the school.''
 As Mr. Azzaro put it, ''The school board believes in the arts and are willing to support us.''
 In Ocean County, Ms. Defibaugh, the supervisor of fine arts , said the Toms River school board has always been supportive of the arts, replacing broken band instruments and adding new classes, like art history and a studio art class. But she said she was concerned that midsize districts, caught in a tight budget cycles, might not be as fortunate.
 ''Art is not a tested subject, so money goes toward English and math since those scores are published in the newspaper and people judge your district on that,'' she said. 
 While recognizing the squeeze on local school districts, Ms. Davy, the state's acting education commissioner, said additional funds are not necessarily the answer. To that end, she said she was hoping the art survey would shine a light on ways to offer innovative arts programming. 
 ''We have to look at the results and see how we might better invest the resources we are investing to address the arts,'' Ms. Davy said, noting that some of the required core art content could be incorporated into other subjects, like math.
 Because the survey is compulsory, officials are expecting 100 percent compliance. Once the survey results are in, the Department of State will take over the job of tabulating the results. The state has hired a statistician who will take the raw numbers provided by each school district, and compare those with other available data -- like population demographics and standardized test scores -- to get a better picture of factors that could be influencing arts programming. 
 Those involved with the project are hoping the survey results will provide the basis for a groundswell of support for arts education.
 ''The findings will allow advocates in the field to rally around some data and be able to say 'We've got to do better,''' said Mr. Pietrowski, who predicted that the survey will uncover ''marked improvement in some districts and backsliding in others.''
 Taking a scientific approach to the arts may seem counterintuitive, but it may be the only way to get a better picture of what is actually happening, said Mr. Morrison, who is coordinating the art survey.
 ''With data, you take the emotions out of the debate,'' he said. ''Without data, you're just another guy with an opinion.''

HEADLINE: Who Is Ronald Rice Anyway?

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
EVEN in the best of times, Ronald L. Rice has a reputation for excitability.
 But now that he is running for mayor, the rail-thin state senator and former city councilman has become so edgy that he can be sent flying into extended bouts of finger-wagging vitriol at the simple mention of a name: Cory Booker.
''Don't you know who Mr. Booker is?'' Mr. Rice asked, glaring at his questioner through thick glasses. ''Coming from out of nowhere with his academic spin? 'I went to college. I'm a Rhodes Scholar. I got a lot of money coming in. If I have a lot of money it means nobody cam beat me.' Oh, no, no, no, no, no, no. Money don't vote. People vote. And we know that in Newark. And we know when we're being bought.''
 In some ways, Mr. Rice, 60, has been building toward this moment his entire life. 
 A Vietnam veteran and former Newark police officer, Mr. Rice has served for the past two decades as a public official in Trenton and Newark, and has long wanted to be mayor.
 With Mayor Sharpe James finally on the sideline after announcing last month that he would not seek re-election to a sixth term, Mr. Rice jumped into this year's race, only to find himself in the path of a political juggernaut.
 That would be Mr. Booker, 36, a graduate of Stanford and Yale Law School by way of Harrington Park, in Bergen County, who has become something of a national political celebrity. Since losing a bitterly fought race to Mr. James in 2002 -- his campaign was later celebrated in the Oscar-nominated documentary ''Street Fight'' -- Mr. Booker has built up enough support this time around to hold a 43-percentage-point lead over Mr. Rice, according to a recent poll by The Star-Ledger. 
 So far, he has raised $6 million in campaign funds from a donor list studded with famous names. And unlike the last time, Mr. Booker is being supported by much of Newark's political establishment. 
 Mr. Booker's political formidability is such that when the mayor finally dropped out of the race March 27, it seemed to many longtime observers of Newark politics that Mr. James was bowing to something inevitable -- a long-awaited changing of the generational guard. And Mr. Rice's belated entry into the contest as a last-gasp champion of the old guard has hardly altered that feeling.
 ''Ron Rice is in a bind,'' said Walter Fields, a former political director of the N.A.A.C.P. ''I think time has elapsed his opportunity. He is on the trailing edge of a generation that is now seeing their exit from the political scene, and he is, unfortunately a victim of timing. Probably his best chance at seeing City Hall as mayor was 15 or 20 years ago. But politics is all about timing, and his is terrible.''
 So why is he running?
 As Mr. Fields views the situation, it is just something Mr. Rice has wanted to do for a long time. ''I think Ron's always had an aspiration to be mayor,'' he said. ''Anyone who sits on the City Council at one time envisions themselves as being the mayor. I don't think they lose that sentiment even when the odds are against them, and I think he feels he has some claim as a candidate because of his long public service.''
 Mr. Rice ran for mayor in 1998, losing by a lopsided margin to his on-again-off-again ally, Mr. James. He says he is motivated to make his latest run to avert what he paints as a takeover of Newark by hostile conservatives in other parts of the country using Mr. Booker as their proxy.
 ''We're George Washington's army,'' Mr. Rice said in an interview in his storefront campaign office on South Orange Avenue, reaching for what has become his favorite historical analogy in this campaign. ''Like I told you. Just like the British came in well equipped, the British came in looking good and organized, the George Washington army had a cause to fight for. It was to save America from the grip of the British. Newarkers have a cause to fight for, and it is to save Newark from the grips of big-money people from Arkansas and all those places we talked about, the far-right of the Republican Party.'' 
 The well-worn racially tinged theme of protecting Newark from outsiders that Mr. James used to such good effect in 2002 comes easily to Mr. Rice, whose lifelong connection to the community and local-boy-made-good biography is inarguably strong. He is a decorated Marine Corps veteran, a graduate of the Rutgers University School of Criminal Justice and a former police detective. 
 It is a fact that Mr. Booker moved to Newark less than a decade ago when he ran for City Council, and that he has attracted financial support from a diverse group of donors made up largely of non-Newark residents that includes some conservatives. But Mr. Rice has had a hard time articulating a clear policy rationale for his candidacy in the May 9 election, and listening to him can at times seem like being in a time warp as he returns to the rhetorical flourishes the mayor employed against Mr. Booker four years ago.
 ''What's he running for?'' Mr. Rice asked, without waiting for an answer. ''Where's he running to? Or where's he running from? But nobody want to know. The media says, 'But don't talk about that. That's not important.' Well, you know what? To you it's not important but to the people that have to live here, it is very important because the biggest mistake we can make is to turn this city over to someone who is not worthy.''
 He said voters were constantly telling him, ''You can't let him in here.'' He added that ''some people'' have told him that Mr. Booker, a light-complexioned African-American running in a city more than 80 percent minority, looks strange. ''You know, in terms of his eyes,'' Mr. Rice said.
 Mr. Booker, who has largely ignored Mr. Rice since Mr. James's decision not to run again, could not resist going after the senator recently over his campaign's relentlessly personal focus. ''All I've heard from him in public forums is that he agrees with all my policies,'' he told reporters at a public event last week. ''His problems with me are issues of personality. It's all personal. To me, it has not been an adequate discussion of issues. I've heard him talk about 27-point plans and 10-point plans, but I haven't seen anything in print.''
 To a certain extent, Mr. Rice does not disagree. Asked what his differences were with Mr. Booker on issues that have arisen in Newark's nonpartisan election, Mr. Rice paused. ''The issues?'' he said. ''Well No. 1, you don't have the C.E.O. of a major corporation just come out of college. O.K.? So it's a matter of experience, No. 1.''
 Reminded that the question was about policy issues, Mr. Rice said: ''Well, I think that he doesn't know how to treat crime. He has an approach that has no real substance to it. I have the experience and know how to make it happen.'' 
 Although Mr. Booker has yet to say how much many of his proposals would cost, he has said how he would deal with issues like policing and, more controversially, education, where his support for vouchers and charter schools has fueled opponents' accusations that he is a closet right-winger. 
 By contrast, Mr. Rice, who has a long record of policymaking from his State Senate years, has talked almost exclusively in generic terms about his experience. With even the most optimistic voters here keenly aware of the city's problems of crime, unemployment and failing schools, it is a risky strategy. ''I don't think you can really campaign on the platform of 'I'm not the other guy' when you haven't really defined yourself,'' Mr. Fields said. Such a consideration is a nonissue to Mr. Rice as he gearsup for an in-the-streets campaign that he insists will close the yawning gap in the polls. He belatedly has the trappings of a functioning campaign: sound trucks, phone banks, two campaign offices stocked with snacks for volunteers and several experienced political operatives aligned with four City Council members who were aligned with the mayor and are now running with Mr. Rice. 
 Mr. Rice has the enthusiastic backing of the 5,000-member Newark teachers union because of the vouchers issue, which he staunchly opposes. However belatedly, he appears to have Mr. James's support. He said last week for the first time that he intended to endorse his deputy mayor.
 So even though Mr. Booker now has the support of most of the city's major unions, three incumbent council members, the city's best-known get-out-the-vote field coordinator and the state's most accomplished Democratic media firm, Mr. Rice is not ready to concede.
 ''I'm not an underdog,'' he said, angrily dismissing the notion as more spin from the Booker campaign. ''See, he keeps painting me as the underdog. That's not what the telephones are telling us. That's not what the streets are telling us.'' 
 Most important, he said, he had a plan.
 ''I'm taking it right to people and taking it to Booker,'' he said. ''I'm going to smoke him out. He's going to come out there talking negative about me? He's going to come out there trying to defend himself. But somehow I'm getting him out of his cubbyhole, because I know the real Cory Booker and the real Cory Booker story. And the real Cory Booker story will be told.''

 Ronald L. Rice has work to do to close the gap with Cory Booker. (Photo by John Marshal Mantel for The New York Times)(pg. 6)

LENGTH: 810 words

HEADLINE: Cory Booker for Mayor

 BODY:
On May 9, when Newark's voters go to the polls, the curtain will drop on the memorable and controversial reign of Sharpe James. For the first time since 1986, Mr. James is not on the ballot in Newark's mayoral election. 
 We believe that Newark's new leader should be Cory Booker, who is running for mayor for the second time. 
 Four years ago, as a 32-year-old rookie councilman, Mr. Booker took on Mr. James in a fierce but vain battle that inspired an Oscar-nominated documentary feature called, with good reason, ''Street Fight.'' Mr. Booker was subjected to race-based taunting and worse, but still managed to give Mr. James a scare.
 There was never any question that Mr. Booker would try again. But the much-awaited sequel has a late-breaking plot twist: Mr. James's decision, announced several weeks ago, not to seek a sixth term. Mr. Booker's chief adversary thus became not the incumbent but the incumbent's former deputy, State Senator Ronald Rice.
 Mr. Rice planned to run only if Mr. James retired. So, while Mr. James was making up his mind, Mr. Rice waited on the sidelines. He has had little time to mount an effective campaign. His fund-raising has barely broken six figures, while Mr. Booker's treasury has grown to more than $4 million. Mr. Rice cannot explain clearly where he differs with Mr. Booker, except to say that he believes Mr. Booker speaks too negatively about the city.
 If that's so, Mr. Booker has much material from which to draw. While Newark under Mayor James boasted of being the nation's Renaissance City, the city's undeniable successes strain under the continued burdens of crime, poverty, poorly performing schools and corruption.
 Even as suburbanites file up and down the McCarter Highway on their way to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, even as young New Yorkers flock to the vibrant shops and restaurants of the Ironbound neighborhood, even as students by the tens of thousands trudge to class at places like Rutgers-Newark, Seton Hall Law School and the New Jersey Institute of Technology, Newark remains desperately in need of leadership, economic development and new ideas. 
 About 30 percent of the city's residents live below the poverty line. Unemployment rates -- 12 percent overall, greater for those in their late teens and early 20's -- and school dropout rates are alarmingly high.
 Mr. Booker rightly asserts that these figures are unacceptable. Likewise, so is the upsurge in violent crime and violence in the public schools. Murders increased from 83 in 2003 to 97 last year. A recent killing on Halsey Street -- carried out, police say, by a man who said he wanted to celebrate his birthday by shooting somebody -- was a chilling reminder that Newark still can be a dangerous place.
 To combat both the sad realities and the even worse perceptions of his adopted city, Mr. Booker, a native of Bergen County, has offered several hard-headed recommendations:
 He says he will put more police on the street, and vows to adopt technology to bring crime under control, as New York did with the Comstat crime-tracking program. He makes a strong case that the city's Police Department is top-heavy with managers chosen more for their political connections than their competence.
 He will bring policy experts to City Hall, rather than rely on political patronage and cronyism, in an effort to lure new investment to a city blessed with first-rate mass transportation connections to New York.
 He will put an end to fire sales of city-owned property to politically connected developers.
 Not all of Mr. Booker's ideas are equally compelling. For example, he refuses to rule out vouchers as part of his remedy for Newark's schools. He now notes with care that he supports vouchers financed with private, not public, dollars. But the next mayor should be devoting his energy to fixing the public schools, and not be sidetracked by schemes that would at best rescue a small fraction of the needy students. 
 Mr. Booker himself remains something of a question mark. His political career, after all, consists of a single term on the Municipal Council. As mayor, will he be able to work with the Council if it remains in the hands of Mr. James's loyalists? Will he be able to persuade his well-heeled supporters to invest in his city, not just his campaign? 
 Undisciplined and unfocused in 2002, Mr. Booker has been shrewd and practical this time around. That is just as well, because the task awaiting him requires those very attributes. Let's not forget, after all, that Newark is home to a pair of powerful state senators whose names will be familiar to him: Sharpe James (yes, he holds two jobs) and Ronald Rice. The two senators will be in a position either to help or hurt Mr. Booker.
 Neither the city nor a new administration needs another street fight. This Election Day ought to be about new beginnings.

SECTION: Section 14; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk; 75 YEARS: F. Y. I.; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 606 words

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK. 
E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com

 BODY:

Q. I am fascinated by the ever-changing multicolored lighting on top of the Empire State Building. Could you tell me the schedule?

A. Only the highlights. Most gazers probably don't realize how often the lighting system changes and how many groups, causes, nations and holidays are honored. The building's Web site, www.esbnyc.com, lists 67 combinations of up to three colors that have been used. (Examples of color schemes and the subjects they have celebrated can be found atop the pages of this section.)
The possibilities are seemingly endless. For example, as one reads the colors from the bottom up, as a pedestrian would see them, lavender-lavender-white honors the anniversary of the Stonewall uprising. Yellow has celebrated the U.S. Open tennis tournament, among other topics. Purple-purple-gold honored the golden jubilee day of Queen Elizabeth II. 
 Just looking up won't tell you everything. Are you looking at red-blue-white? You could be seeing a commemoration of Philippine independence or the colors of the New York Rangers. Blue -- just blue -- has been used to commemorate more than a dozen subjects, including Unicef, Boys and Girls Clubs, child abuse prevention and Jazz at Lincoln Center.
 If you want to light the building pink for Mom's birthday, sorry. Building policy does not allow lighting for commercial or corporate events, or personal celebrations, though requests are taken for nonprofit or charitable celebrations. 
 To avoid the risk to birds, which are attracted to the lights, the tower lights are turned off during spring and fall migration seasons and on some cloudy, humid or foggy nights, when large numbers of birds are seen flying near the building.
 The Empire State Building has been lighted to some degree since November 1932, when a searchlight beacon alerted the public to Franklin D. Roosevelt's election as president. Colored lighting came in 1976. 
 Installed in each of the four faces of the topmost mast are four vertical banks of 11 eight-foot panels positioned one on top of another, for a total of 176 panels. A ring of 32 sodium vapor lights above the 102nd floor was installed in 1984 to create a golden halo effect around the top of the mast from dusk to dawn.

Q. When I was on the Empire State Building's observation deck, I got to wondering why the building stopped where it did. I've read that buildings could have been built much higher.

A. It's true; buildings could have gone higher. In 1956, Frank Lloyd Wright even sketched a design for a mile-high 528-story skyscraper in Illinois.
 But the Empire State Building, to say nothing of Wright's behemoth, was limited by economic factors. As a building rises higher, more structural steel and bracing are required, lowering the amount of rentable space and increasing costs. While the Empire State Building was being planned, the American Institute of Steel Construction issued a report estimating that a skyscraper's rate of economic return declined if it went higher than 63 stories. 
 But perhaps the major factor limiting height was the elevators. As floors went higher, more passengers had to be served and the elevator cables were longer. Wider shafts were needed, reducing rentable space.
 Balancing speed with comfort is a juggling act. The acceleration of elevators has to be tolerable for riders' knees and stomachs. The Empire State elevators travel as fast as 1,000 feet a minute.
 For the record, the Empire State Building stands 1,250 feet tall. A broadcasting antenna adds 204 feet to the overall height, making it 1,454 feet. An earlier antenna, which stood from 1951 to 1984, was 18 feet taller. MICHAEL POLLAK

HEADLINE: The 'Sky Boys'

BYLINE: By JIM RASENBERGER. 
Jim Rasenberger is the author of ''High Steel: The Daring Men Who Built the World's Greatest Skyline,'' a history of New York's ironworkers.

 BODY:
THE shy, slight man who showed up on 34th Street one spring day carrying a four-by-five Graflex camera probably failed to make a powerful first impression on the workers he'd been hired to photograph. He wore owlish glasses, his ears stuck out, and his demeanor was that of the bookish schoolteacher he once had been. Altogether, he looked as if he could be blown off a steel beam by a stiff breeze.
 Lewis Wickes Hine was easily underestimated. But from the moment he'd quit his job at the Ethical Culture School two decades earlier to devote his life to photography, he had proved himself brave and resourceful, not to mention enormously gifted. During his early years of photographing children in coal mines in Pennsylvania and cotton mills in South Carolina, he often posed as a Bible salesman or a life insurance agent to gain entry, then slipped away before he could be discovered and beaten up. The haunting portraits Hine brought back from those expeditions galvanized child labor laws in America and made him the pre-eminent documentary photographer of the Progressive era. 
But by 1930 all that was long behind. Hine's brand of sociological concern was out of fashion, and his photographs were out of favor. The onset of the Depression only reduced the chance that this washed-up 56-year-old would find decent work with his camera. Still, when the phone call came from his old friend Belle Moskowitz, who was working as the Empire State Building's publicist, he must have hesitated before accepting her offer to become the building's official photographer. On one hand, it meant selling out to the kind of corporate interest he had long disdained. On the other hand, he needed the money.
 Hine was hired to photograph all aspects of the building's construction, but it is obvious from his photographs that he found his most stirring subject in the structural ironworkers. These men -- ''sky boys,'' as Hine would come to call them -- raised the building's steel frame, balancing on airy perches to join columns and beams, leading the way upward as the other trades followed from below. A tight-knit, swashbuckling clan of Newfoundlanders, Mohawk Indians, Scandinavians and Irish-Americans, they were self-proclaimed ''roughnecks'' who, as the New York Times writer C. G. Poore put it at the time, spent their days ''strolling on the thin edge of nothingness.'' 
 Hine understood that to photograph the men who raised steel, it would not do to stand on the pavement. He would have to enter their element, to climb out among them at high altitude and take the chances they took. One of Hine's more ingenious techniques was to have himself hoisted in an open steel box rigged to a derrick line so that he could dangle over the ironworkers, a quarter-mile above the ground. Thus, he managed to capture, as no one had before, the dizzying and sometimes marvelous work of building skyscrapers. 
 That work had never been so marvelous as it was on 34th Street in the spring and summer of 1930. Under Hine's eye, the ironworkers raised 57,000 tons of steel in just six months, almost 50 percent more than the amount used in the Chrysler and Bank of Manhattan buildings combined. 
 Hine's photographs of the men, later collected in a volume called ''Men at Work,'' convey an almost palpable appreciation of their physical labor. While his earlier reform-minded photographs portray his working-class subjects as sympathetic victims, those from the Empire State Building treat them as heroes: muscle-bound men, with strong jaw lines and sun-bleached hair, conquering gravity and steel. 
 They stand on airy perches, hang off guy wires and catch rides on the steel balls of derricks, all the while brimming with confidence and derring-do. The world below may have been descending into economic despair, but these are images of unabashed optimism. And whatever success the Empire State Building later achieved as architecture or real estate, Hine's photographs sealed its status as a stunning human endeavor, animating its steel and brick with something like soul. Even today, it is difficult to look up from 34th Street without conjuring one of Hine's sky boys clambering among the clouds, and the building is better for it.
 After the steel frame topped out in November 1930, the workers dispersed and returned to less glorified work or, in the grip of the Depression, to none at all. Hine returned to his home in Hastings-on-Hudson and to mounting financial difficulties. The photographs he had taken on the Empire State Building would later fetch tens of thousands of dollars and become among the best-known images in the world, but they did little to help his foundering career at the time. When he died 10 years later, he was destitute.
 For those months in 1930, though, both the photographer and the ironworkers were at the top of their games, and each gave the other an invaluable gift. Hine gave the men a degree of honor and immortality that is rarely bestowed on blue-collar workers. They, in turn, lent his photographs their exhilarating pride and grace, and inspired some of the greatest work of his life. 

'Everybody Seems to Think You Have to Be a Superman'
 THE names and biographies of most of the men who worked on the Empire State Building are lost now. But one of Lewis Wickes Hine's photography subjects left behind a few words to explain himself when a journalist visited him during a lunch break on the 84th floor. His name was Victor Gosselin; he was known to his fellow ironworkers simply as ''Frenchy'' because he had been raised in Montreal. Frenchy was a connector, one of the especially agile ironworkers whose task was to snatch steel from the sky as it came sailing in on the boom of the derrick, then wrangle it into the building's frame.
 In Hine's photographs, Frenchy is shirtless and wears cutoff jeans that reveal cuts and bruises on his legs. That a connector, who shinnies up and down rusted steel columns all day, would wear shorts is beyond imagining, but there he is, taking a trip on the derrick ball, a half grin on his face as his shorts ride up like a chorus girl's.
 ''Everybody seems to think you have to be a superman or something to work on steel,'' Frenchy told the journalist. ''Of course, it ain't no picnic, but then there's lots of jobs I'd pass up for this. I wouldn't want to be no taxi driver, for instance. Look at them down there, dodging in and out of that traffic all day long. A guy's apt to get killed that way.'' 
 Munching on a huge steak sandwich, Frenchy revealed that he had come close to getting killed several times in falls and had seen dozens of other men die. What did his wife think of his work? ''She don't think nothing about it. You don't see Lindbergh's wife telling him he can't fly around in airplanes, do you?'' Frenchy shrugged.
 ''I don't know,'' he added. ''She never says nothing but 'Goodbye, baby; don't get hurt.' '' JIM RASENBERGER

HEADLINE: Diamond District

BYLINE: By DAVE CALDWELL

 BODY:
AS recently as 1993, the New York area was a backwater for minor league baseball. After all, it had the Yankees and the Mets, who between them played a total of 162 home games a year.
 There was one minor league team -- the Red Sox in New Britain, Conn. -- in an area embracing Connecticut, New Jersey and a chunk of New York, including Long Island and Westchester and Dutchess Counties.
Last year the Yankees and the Mets drew a total of 6.9 million fans, 2.7 million more than in 1993. But these days 16 minor league teams share that same swath of land, and at least 3 more are on the way, leading some fans to wonder: How much of a good -- and sometimes not-so-good -- thing can even the most ardent baseball fan stand?
 The fact is, New York City and its suburbs have become a hotbed for minor league baseball, saturating the region with more clubs any other part of the country. And if a Yankees or Mets game is akin to taking in a Broadway play, then a minor league game is like a trip to a neighborhood cineplex. 
 ''It's Hometown U.S.A.,'' said James P. Molinaro, the borough president of Staten Island, which is home to the Yankees' New York-Penn League team. ''And it gives the parent an opportunity to go out and see some baseball with his family without spending $400.''
 Tickets, as well as peanuts, popcorn and hot dogs, are substantially less expensive in the minors than in the big leagues. The best seat in the house for a Staten Island Yankees game costs $11; a seat at the top of the upper deck of Yankee Stadium is $20. 
 Of course, players in the minor leagues are far less polished than their big-league counterparts, but most people who go to a game already know that. The quality of play is not much better than it is at, say, a local college game. And the age of most of the players is similar. Only one of the 26 players on the current roster of the Lakewood BlueClaws, the Philadelphia Phillies' Class A affiliate, has celebrated his 24th birthday. 
 Still, minor league officials like to say they have built an audience by emphasizing the notion that a night of baseball in Lakewood, Coney Island or Bridgeport is affordable family entertainment.
 It is an appeal that has resonated. 
 In 2005, the 16 minor league teams in the area drew a total of 3,835,689 fans, or slightly fewer than the record 4,090,440 the Yankees drew last year while playing in a stadium about 10 times the size of an average minor league park.
 While minor league fans will not see Alex Rodriguez swatting a home run for the Yankees or Pedro Martinez pitching to perfection for the Mets, they may get to cavort with a fuzzy mascot or participate in a three-legged race between innings.
 ''If people leave the park without knowing who won or lost the game, then we have done our job,'' said Jim Beaudoin, the general manager of the Connecticut Defenders of the Eastern League.

More Than a Ballpark
 Indeed, minor league baseball has become such a cottage industry that it is now regarded as a way to lure families and large groups into redeveloped areas where baseball is just one attraction. Retail shops, restaurants, office space and hotels are often other parts of the package.
 But a minor league ballpark does not guarantee that the area around it will be developed. For instance, KeySpan Park on Coney Island, where the Brooklyn Cyclones, a Mets' farm team, have played to capacity crowds since 2001, does not appear to have changed its surroundings much.
 ''If a ballpark is not part of a larger urban redevelopment, it's not going to be successful,'' said Mary-Jane Foster, a real estate developer who with her husband, Jack McGregor, owns and operates the Bridgeport Bluefish, an Atlantic League team in Connecticut. The couple bought the team in December.
 That lesson has not been lost on Mr. McGregor and Ms. Foster, who own one of three Atlantic League expansion teams on the drawing board. In their case, a ballpark in Yonkers is to be the jewel of a $3.1-billion downtown renovation project.
 The two other proposals for the Atlantic League, which was founded in 1998 and is made up of independent teams with no major league ties, call for new stadiums to be built as part of Meadowlands Xanadu, a shopping center and entertainment complex going up in the Meadowlands Sports Complex, and a project in Nassau County on Long Island.
 For now, Steven B. Kalafer -- a developer and owner of about 30 automobile dealerships who at one time had a stake in every team in the Atlantic League except the Atlantic City Surf -- also owns a franchise called the Bergen Cliff Hawks, which he planned to have play at a ballpark at Xanadu. But for now, the financially troubled developers of Xanadu have failed to produce a plan for the park and Mr. Kalafer is suing them. 
 The Nassau County team, which still does not have a name, will be operated by Frank Boulton, the founder and commissioner of the Atlantic League and the owner of three of its teams, including the Long Island Ducks. The Ducks have played to capacity crowds at the 6,002-seat Citibank Park in Central Islip since the league began in 1998.
 Mr. Boulton does not seem to be concerned that his new team will play its home games just 25 miles west of the Ducks, who drew 429,218 to 70 home dates last season. He conceded in a recent interview that the landscape could become too cluttered with minor league teams, but he insisted that point had not yet been reached. 
 As Mr. Kalafer said, ''The region was simply under-served.''
 That is not to say that owning a minor league team in the region is a ticket to success. 

Nearly Saturated?
 Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who is a leading authority on the business of sports, said in a telephone interview that in general, it is hard to have too many minor league teams, since fans prefer to travel only minutes to a game. But he said the New York area might be nearly saturated. 
 ''I'm exaggerating here, but it's a little bit like having a bowling alley in each community,'' he said. 
 ''It sounds to me like 16 is too many,'' Mr. Zimbalist said of New York's crop of teams. ''You can certainly have a glut.''
 Take the New Jersey Cardinals, a farm club of the St. Louis Cardinals. At the end of last season, they moved from Sussex County to a new ballpark in State College, Pa., where the team will be called the Spikes. Or the Ravens, an Eastern League affiliate of the Toronto Blue Jays, who left New Haven, Conn., for Manchester, N.H., where a new ballpark was completed after the 2003 season.
 ''Yale Field did not have some of the amenities you'd like to have in a modern ballpark,'' said Charlie Dowd, the former general manager of the Ravens, who is now general manager of the Bridgeport Bluefish.
 But just as quickly as teams move to other homes, new ones take their place. Sussex County and New Haven quickly lured franchises from the Can-Am League, another independent league. The New Haven County Cutters entered the league in 2004, and the Sussex Skyhawks will make their debut this season.
 The Cutters' management spruced up Yale Field, a charming ballpark in West Haven, Conn. As for the Skyhawks, the team spent $1.5 million renovating Skylands Park, in Augusta, yet it sliced ticket and concession prices to woo back fans, and it is focusing heavily on group sales. A box seat that had cost $12 is now $10, and hot dogs, which sold for $3.25, now cost $2.50. 
 ''I absolutely think it's a gold mine,'' said the general manager of the Skyhawks, Ben Wittkowski, who had worked for the New Jersey Jackals, another team in the Can-Am League in Montclair. ''It's the only game in town.'' 
 Although the Long Island and Somerset teams have always attracted large crowds, other Atlantic League teams have struggled. The Nashua Pride, in New Hampshire, switched to the Can-Am League during the off-season, obliging the Atlantic League to find a new eighth team to balance its schedule.
 Another of Mr. Boulton's teams, the Atlantic City Surf, averaged 2,018 fans a game last year at its 5,900-seat stadium, the Sandcastle, and the Newark Bears, owned in part by Mr. Kalafer until late last year, averaged 2,709 in 2005 at their 6,200-seat home park. 
 ''But this will really be the first season since the park has opened that there's not construction going on in front of the site,'' Mr. Kalafer said.
 Last season, the Bluefish averaged only 3,036 fans a game at the 5,300-seat Ballpark at Harbor Yard. Mr. Dowd, the general manager, said the team did not have enough money to advertise, a crucial component to success in the minors. 
 Ms. Foster, one of the new owners of the team, said the push is on to make the Bluefish enticing to suburban mothers, who usually make the entertainment decisions for their families.
 ''It has not made money,'' she said. ''But we also believe that it can.''
 Indeed, Ms. Foster says she is so sure of the drawing power of minor league teams that she and her husband plan to run an Atlantic League team in Yonkers, N.Y., where the stadium will be the hub of that city's redevelopment when it is completed, starting in 2008. 
 ''We were really amazed at how Yonkers has turned itself around,'' she said.
 Even though the downtown area of Yonkers, a city of 200,000, is less than 10 miles from Yankee Stadium and less than 20 miles from Shea, Mayor Philip A. Amicone says the team will not compete for customers with New York's two big-league teams.
 ''To travel to Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium costs a fortune for a family,'' he said. ''Now, Yonkers is going to be a place where people want to come again.''
 The ballparks on the drawing board for the Meadowlands and in Nassau County will not be in the middle of existing urban areas, but the goal is the same: to draw those seeking affordable family entertainment to a site that also has offices, shops and restaurants.

A Late Addition
 In fact, a ballpark was not originally included in Charles B. Wang's plan to renovate Nassau Coliseum, the home of his two franchises, the New York Islanders of hockey and the Dragons of arena football. 
 In addition to a refurbished arena and a sports technology center, Mr. Wang, founder of Computer Associates, wants to build office towers, hotels, apartment buildings and town houses on the site.
 Mr. Wang and Reckson Associates, his development partner, were awarded the project last month over a rival bid by the owners of the Mets, in part because they added a minor league ballpark to their plan to match the one the Mets proposed.
 The Meadowlands Xanadu development is no less ambitious. Besides a luxury hotel and office buildings, the Mills Corporation, the lead developer of the site, has vowed that Xanadu will be a 4.8-million-square-foot ''entertainment destination.''
 What Bergen County stands to gain -- if a ballpark is ever built there -- is a team that it truly can call its own.
 ''It's a community builder, it's something that can bring pride to a community,'' said Steve Cohen, the general manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones. ''We realize that not everyone who comes to a Cyclones game is a die-hard baseball fan.''
 As Mr. Cohen put it: ''For every two people who, walking in, are baseball fans, there are two people who aren't. But they leave with a smile on their faces, just like the baseball fans do.''

Leagues of Their Own
 When it comes to minor league baseball, it's hard to tell the teams apart without a scorecard.
 Today there are eight minor league teams in New Jersey, four in Connecticut, two in New York City and one each on Long Island and in Dutchess County in New York, representing five different leagues. Three of those leagues -- the Eastern, South Atlantic and New York-Penn Leagues -- consist of farm teams of major league clubs.
 The Eastern League is a Class AA league, meaning that its players are two steps from the majors, and the South Atlantic League is Class A, three steps away. Teams in each of the two leagues, which opened the season earlier this month, play 140 games a season
 The New York-Penn League is a short-season Class A league, and teams -- made up largely of players who tend to be younger and less skilled than in the long-season Class A league -- play a 76-game schedule beginning in June.
 In addition, two independent leagues, the Atlantic and the Can-Am, have teams in the area. Neither league has ties to the majors, but big-league clubs often raid independent teams to stock their rosters. Of the two leagues, the Atlantic, which plays a 136-game schedule that opens this week, tends to have players who have accomplished more as professionals.
 The most notable Atlantic League player in recent years was Rickey Henderson, the former Yankees and Mets outfielder and the major-league career leader in stolen bases, who played for the Newark Bears in 2003 before signing a contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers midway through the major-league season.
 The Can-Am League, which plays a 92-game schedule that begins in late May, has younger players hoping to impress scouts from major league teams that want to fill the rosters of their minor affiliates. DAVE CALDWELL

HEADLINE: Poorer School Districts Practice Higher Math to Pay Leaders

BYLINE: By FORD FESSENDEN

 BODY:
OSSINING is one of the poorer school districts in Westchester, and its students' achievement levels are average. But in one category, it is competitive with the best districts in the state: Its administrators are well paid.
 Superintendent Robert J. Roelle is one of a small but growing group of superintendents who make more than $300,000 in salary and benefits, according to information compiled by the State Education Department. And with 26 assistant superintendents, principals and department chairmen and women making at least $104,000, Ossining has one of the largest contingents of six-figure executives in the state: about 6 per 1,000 students, a level rivaled only by a few other districts in Westchester and Long Island.
''It's more than the governor makes,'' Irwin Kavy, the school board president, said of Dr. Roelle's salary. ''It's extremely high.''
 Across suburban New York, salaries of school administrators are testing new heights. Districts, competing to give the children of their affluent residents every advantage, have helped create a seller's market for management talent that has pushed some superintendents into the thin air of the $300,000 salary-and-benefit package. 
 Meanwhile, the $200,000 milestone -- effectively the floor for superintendent pay now -- has become increasingly common among deputy and assistant superintendents. Fifty-six school administrators in Westchester now make more than $200,000 in total compensation, and 19 of them are assistants or deputies.
 Every year, districts must report to the state any administrator whom they pay more than a certain figure, now set at $104,000. Some fail to do so, and state officials say they have no way of enforcing the law, unless they get a complaint from a citizen. In Westchester this year, however, salaries for all but 2 of the more than 40 districts were available. 
 School board members like Mr. Kavy, under pressure to deliver higher test scores, say they must pay well enough to lure and retain good people for that task. But as scandals and rising taxes put administration under a microscope, the strain is beginning to show.
 ''Our administrators for the most part work extremely hard, they work long days and hours,'' Mr. Kavy said. ''But it is a lot of money, and it's very hard to justify the high compensation packages, other than to say it's the system, and the competition for limited resources.''
 The median increase in total compensation of superintendents in the county was 8.6 percent last year, according to data reported to the Education Department. Inflation advanced just 3.3 percent in that time.
 The median increase for assistant and deputy superintendents was nearly as much, 7.8 percent. Principals' pay also advanced, but it is more difficult to calculate the rate from the figures compiled by the state because some principals make less than the threshold and their salaries are not reported. Nor are principals' benefits reported individually.
 School boards and their supporters say they are caught in a squeeze that is only partly of their own making. Demand has increased because a cohort of teachers hired in the late 1960's, who became administrators in the 1980's and 1990's, is now retiring. Boards are looking to replace about 80 of the state's approximately 750 superintendents each year, instead of the usual 40 or 45, according to Thomas Rogers, executive director of the New York State Council of School Superintendents.
 But supply has dwindled, officials contend, because administrative jobs have become less attractive. 
 ''The job has become incredibly complex,'' said Vincent T. Beni, a recruiter and former superintendent in Irvington. ''Fiscal constraints are imposed from outside, and they drive a lot of the decisions. The imposition of mandates from state and federal government are not funded, and require you to go out and ask people to raise their taxes to pay for them. When I first started, we were education leaders of the community. Now, you've become a fund-raiser.''
 In a 2003 survey, the school superintendents council found that the average age at which a superintendent first took a top district job was 48, compared with 38 in the early 1990's.
 Mr. Rogers said that is partly a demographic issue: women, who tend to be given the top job at an older age than men are, now account for 22 percent of superintendents in the state, up from 12 percent in 1997.
 But, he said, higher age levels are also a barometer of reluctance: The job is hard, especially in the small districts where residents expect a lot and costs are soaring.
 ''The environment is more hostile,'' he said. ''The tension has never been greater because the demand has never been greater and the costs have never been greater.'' 
 DONNA WALSH, the school board president in the Katonah-Lewisboro district, said: ''In an affluent community like ours, the people are very sophisticated, they're very demanding and you work in this fishbowl. It's a very challenging job.''
 Part of the reason for the scarcity of administrators at all levels, authorities say, is that teaching has recently become much better paid. Teachers have better job security and work shorter hours for generous benefits, and thousands now make six-figure salaries. In the Bedford Central School District, for instance, the middle school principal made $132,000 in salary last year; the top-paid teacher made $136,279. Those figures don't include benefits.
 ''Our experienced teachers are already making $100,000 and they're working on a 180-day year,'' said Dr. Roelle of Ossining. ''I'm competing with my own internal marketplace of teachers. If I'm not offering a salary that makes it worthwhile to pull them away from families in the summertimes, I'm not going to get the best people.'' 
 Critics dismiss the talk of low supply and high demand and say that cozy relationships between boards and administrators are the reason for the large pay packages. 
 ''To imply there is not a tremendous number of people interested in 126 jobs that are the highest-paid jobs on Long Island, in an industry that is protected by contracts, is a joke,'' said Fred Gorman, a tax protester in Nesconset, N.Y., citing the number of Nassau and Suffolk districts.
 Joseph Auricchio, an Edgemont businessman who opposes hefty school taxes, says superintendents in suburban districts are not only overpaid but also, in some cases, not qualified. ''Superintendents are teachers plucked out of the classroom to do a C.E.O.'s job totally unprepared and inexperienced,'' he said in an e-mail exchange.
 Mr. Kavy echoed those sentiments. He favors changing the state requirement that administrators be certified teachers, which he believes has contributed to the problems. 
 Because of the requirement, he said, ''someone with a great deal of experience in managing, but was never a teacher, can't fill those positions, so there's a shortage of administrators out there.
 ''And it's causing districts to claw over each other to get good ones,'' he said.
 Organizations that represent school boards and superintendents say the elected board members are running too scared before their increasingly rebellious taxpayers to enter into compensation conspiracies with their administrators.
 ''Everyone is obsessed with property tax rates,'' said David Ernst, spokesman for the New York State School Boards Association. ''I don't see where it works to a district's advantage to go wild in bidding up the contracts of superintendents. It's just not what they're thinking about.''
 Still, board members acknowledge that they feel constant pressure to keep their executives, or find new ones, and that the pressure is not likely to abate soon. The stakes are high: With more and more emphasis on measurable achievement, they want administrators who can bolster scores. 
 ''I get calls all the time from other districts,'' said Ms. Walsh, of Katonah-Lewisboro, ''and they have the nerve to say they saw one of our assistant superintendents at a conference, and do I think they'd be interested in a new job?''
 Mr. Ernst argued that the overall bill for central administrators -- not principals, but higher-ranking administrators -- is lower on average in New York districts than in other states. ''There are a lot of highly paid administrators,'' he said, ''but there are not a lot of administrators, so people are being required to earn their money.'' 
 Nevertheless, wage levels are further straining finances. Ossining is typical of those caught in the squeeze: More students who need attention, but less resources to help them. One in 10 Ossining students have limited English proficiency, and one in five come from families with income low enough to qualify for free lunch. In the nearby Briarcliff Manor district, only about one in 1,000 students qualify for free lunch. Yet Ossining has about 50 percent less taxable income per pupil than Briarcliff Manor, according to state calculations. 
 ''We have a diverse student body, and we have a large achievement gap that we're expending huge resources to try to rectify,'' Mr. Kavy said. ''It's good to have a superintendent with lots of experience, but it's tough on the taxpayers who have to pay for it.''

HEADLINE: The Bases Are Loaded

BYLINE: By DAVE CALDWELL

 BODY:
AS recently as 1993, the New York area was a backwater for minor league baseball. After all, it had the Yankees and the Mets, who between them played a total of 162 home games a year.
 There was one minor league team -- the Red Sox in New Britain, Conn. -- in an area embracing Connecticut, New Jersey and a chunk of New York, including Long Island and Westchester and Dutchess Counties.
Last year the Yankees and the Mets drew a total of 6.9 million fans, 2.7 million more than in 1993. But these days 16 minor league teams share that same swath of land, and at least 3 more are on the way, leading some fans to wonder: How much of a good -- and sometimes not-so-good -- thing can even the most ardent baseball fan stand?
 New York City and its suburbs have become a hotbed for minor league baseball, saturating the region with more clubs any other part of the country. And if a Yankees or Mets game is akin to taking in a Broadway play, then a minor league game is like a trip to a neighborhood cineplex. 
 ''It's Hometown U.S.A.,'' said James P. Molinaro, the borough president of Staten Island, which is home to the Yankees' New York-Penn League team. ''And it gives the parent an opportunity to go out and see some baseball with his family without spending $400.''
 Tickets, as well as peanuts, popcorn and hot dogs, are substantially less expensive in the minors than in the big leagues. The best seat in the house for a Staten Island Yankees' game costs $11; a seat at the top of the upper deck of Yankee Stadium is $20.
 Of course, players in the minor leagues are far less polished than their big-league counterparts, but most people who go to a game already know that. The quality of play is not much better than what it is at, say, a local college game. And the age of most of the players is similar. Only one of the 26 players on the current roster of the Lakewood BlueClaws, the Philadelphia Phillies' Class A affiliate, has celebrated his 24th birthday. 
 Still, minor league officials like to say they have built an audience by emphasizing the notion that a night in Lakewood, Coney Island or Bridgeport is affordable family entertainment.
 It is an appeal that has resonated. 
 In 2005, the 16 minor league teams in the area drew a total of 3,835,689 fans, or slightly fewer than the record 4,090,440 the Yankees drew last year while playing in a stadium about 10 times the size of an average minor league park.
 While minor league fans will not get to see Alex Rodriguez swatting a home run for the Yankees or Pedro Martinez pitching to perfection for the Mets, they may get to cavort with a fuzzy mascot or participate in a three-legged race between innings.
 ''If people leave the park without knowing who won or lost the game, then we have done our job,'' said Jim Beaudoin, the general manager of the Connecticut Defenders of the Eastern League, a team based in Norwich.
 Indeed, minor league baseball has become such a cottage industry that it is now regarded as a way to lure families and large groups into redeveloped areas where baseball is just one attraction. Retail shops, restaurants, office space and hotels are often other parts of the package.
 But a minor league ballpark does not guarantee that the area around it will be developed. For instance, KeySpan Park on Coney Island, where the Brooklyn Cyclones, a Mets' farm team, have played to capacity crowds since 2001, does not appear to have changed its surroundings much.
 ''If a ballpark is not part of a larger urban redevelopment, it's not going to be successful,'' said Mary-Jane Foster, a real estate developer who with her husband, Jack McGregor, owns and operates the Bridgeport Bluefish of the Atlantic League.
 That lesson has not been lost on Mr. McGregor and Ms. Foster, who own one of three Atlantic League expansion teams on the drawing board. In their case, a ballpark in Yonkers is to be the jewel of a $3.1-billion downtown renovation project.
 The two other proposals for the Atlantic League, which was founded in 1998 and is made up of independent teams with no major-league ties, call for new stadiums to be built as part of Meadowlands Xanadu, a shopping center and entertainment complex going up in the Meadowlands Sports Complex in New Jersey, and a project in Nassau County on Long Island.
 For now, Steven B. Kalafer -- a developer and owner of about 30 automobile dealerships who at one time had a stake in every team in the Atlantic League with the exception of the Atlantic City Surf -- also owns a New Jersey franchise called the Bergen Cliff Hawks, which he planned to have play at a ballpark at Xanadu. But for now, the financially troubled developers of Xanadu have failed to produce a plan for the park and Mr. Kalafer is suing them. 
 The Nassau County team, which still does not have a name, will be operated by Frank Boulton, the founder and commissioner of the Atlantic League who already owns three teams in it, including the Long Island Ducks, which has played to capacity crowds at the 6,000-seat Citibank Park in Central Islip since its inception in 1998.
 Mr. Boulton does not seem to be concerned that his new team will be based about 25 miles west of the Ducks, who drew 429,218 to 70 home dates last season. He conceded in a recent interview that the landscape could become too cluttered with minor league teams, although he insisted that point had not yet been reached. 
 As Mr. Kalafer said, ''The region was simply under-served.''
 That is not to say that owning a minor league team in the region is a ticket to success. 
 Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who is a leading authority on sports business, said in a telephone interview that while it is hard to have too many minor league teams -- since fans prefer to travel only minutes to a game -- the New York area might well be reaching that point. 
 ''I'm exaggerating here, but it's a little bit like having a bowling alley in each community,'' he said. 
 But when it comes to the New York area, with 16 minor league teams and more on the way, Mr. Zimbalist said: ''It sounds to me like 16 is too many. You can certainly have a glut.''
 Take the New Jersey Cardinals, a farm club of the St. Louis Cardinals, which at the end of last season moved from Sussex County to a new ballpark in State College, Pa., where the team will be called the Spikes. Or the Ravens, an Eastern League affiliate of the Toronto Blue Jays, who left New Haven, Conn., for Manchester, N.H., where a new ballpark was completed after the 2003 season.
 ''Yale Field did not have some of the amenities you'd like to have in a modern ballpark,'' said Charlie Dowd, the former general manager of the Ravens who is now general manager of the Bridgeport Bluefish.
 But just as quickly as teams move to other homes, new ones take their place. For instance, Sussex County and New Haven quickly lured franchises from the Can-Am League, another independent league. The New Haven County Cutters entered the league in 2004, and the Sussex Skyhawks will make their debut this season.
 The Cutters' management spruced up Yale Field, a charming ballpark in West Haven, Conn. As for the Skyhawks, the team spent $1.5 million renovating Skylands Park, in Augusta, yet it sliced ticket and concession prices to woo back fans, and it is focusing heavily on group sales. A box seat that had cost $12 is now $10, and hot dogs, which sold for $3.25, now cost $2.50. 
 ''I absolutely think it's a gold mine,'' said the general manager of the Skyhawks, Ben Wittkowski, who had worked for the New Jersey Jackals, another team in the Can-Am League in Montclair. ''It's the only game in town.'' 
 Although the Long Island and Somersetteams have always attracted large crowds, other Atlantic League teams have struggled. The Nashua Pride, in New Hampshire, moved to the Can-Am League during the off-season, forcing the eight-team league to replace them with the Road Warriors -- who do not yet have a home park -- to balance the schedule.
 Another of Mr. Boulton's teams, the Atlantic City Surf, averaged 2,018 fans a game last year at its 5,900-seat stadium, the Sandcastle. The Newark Bears, a New Jersey team that had been owned in part by Mr. Kalafer until late last year, averaged 2,709 in 2005 at the 6,200-seat Bears and Eagles Riverfront Stadium.
 ''But this will really be the first season since the park has opened that there's not construction going on in front of the site,'' Mr. Kalafer said.
 The Bridgeport Bluefish were founded in 1998 by a group of investors that included Ms. Foster and her husband, Mr. McGregor. Another member of the group, Mickey Herbert, bought controlling interest in the club in 2000, but Ms. Foster and Mr. McGregor bought the team from him in December 2005.
 Last season, the Bluefish averaged only 3,036 fans a game at the 5,300-seat Ballpark at Harbor Yard. The team did not have enough money to advertise, a crucial component to success in the minors, said Mr. Dowd, the general manager.
 This year, Ms. Foster said, the push is on to make the Bluefish enticing to suburban mothers, who usually make the entertainment decisions for their families.
 ''It has not made money,'' Ms. Foster said of the club. ''But we also believe that it can, or else we would not have come back.''
 Indeed, Ms. Foster says she is so sure of the drawing power of minor league teams that she and her husband plan to run an Atlantic League team in Yonkers, where the stadium will be the hub of that city's redevelopment when it is completed, probably in 2008. 
 ''We were really amazed at how Yonkers has turned itself around,'' she said.
 Even though the downtown area of Yonkers, a city of 200,000, is less than 10 miles from Yankee Stadium and less than 20 miles from Shea, Mayor Philip A. Amicone believes that the team will not be competing for customers with New York's two big-league teams.
 ''To travel to Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium costs a fortune for a family,'' he said. ''Now, Yonkers is going to be a place where people want to come again.''
 The ballparks on the drawing board for the Meadowlands and in Nassau County will not be in the middle of urban areas, although the goal for each is the same: to draw those seeking affordable family entertainment to a site that also has offices, shops and restaurants.
 In fact, a ballpark was not originally included in Charles B. Wang's plan to renovate Nassau Coliseum, the home of the New York Islanders of the National Hockey League. 
 In addition to a substantially refurbished arena and a sports technology center, Mr. Wang -- the owner of the Islanders and founder of Computer Associates -- wanted his ambitious project to include office towers, hotels, apartment buildings and town houses.
 Mr. Wang and Reckson Associates, a development company based in Long Island that is his partner in the project, were awarded the project last month over a rival bid by the owners of the Mets, in part because they added a 6,000-seat minor league ballpark to their plan to match the one the Mets proposed.
 The Meadowlands Xanadu development is no less ambitious. Besides a luxury hotel and office buildings, the Mills Corporation, the lead developer of the site, has vowed that Xanadu will be a 4.8-million-square-foot ''entertainment destination.''
 What Bergen County stands to gain -- if a ballpark is ever built there -- is a team that it truly can call its own.
 ''It's a community builder, it's something that can bring pride to a community,'' said Steve Cohen, the general manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones. ''We realize that not everyone who comes to a Cyclones game is a die-hard baseball fan.''
 As Mr. Cohen put it: ''For every two people who walking in are baseball fans, there are two people who aren't. But they leave with a smile on their faces, just like the baseball fans do.''

HEADLINE: In Portland Quarries, a Park Huck Finn Might Love

BYLINE: By C. J. HUGHES

 BODY:
THE first time Frank Hayes saw Portland's former brownstone quarries, he was skipping school for a swim.
 That was in 1980. As they were for most of the 20th century, the quarries -- a National Historic Landmark and the source of the building blocks for much of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, as well as parts of Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, San Francisco and London -- were filled at the time with deep, clean water.
So a hot day, he said, was the perfect excuse to borrow a manure truck from the family farm in Rocky Hill for a road trip with his friends.
 ''We would drive down and party all day and then jump in,'' he said. ''It's what kids around here did.'' 
 Now, Mr. Hayes and his brothers Ed and Sean are trying to create a business at the quarries called the Brownstone Exploration and Discovery Park, where people will be able to learn scuba diving and hone their skills in emergency water rescues.
 The location includes 38 acres of water surrounded by brownstone cliffs that are colored and layered like chocolate cake, just feet from the Connecticut River. It is ideal for diving, the brothers said, because the water is so deep -- up to 95 feet in some places -- and clear. You can see 40 feet ahead of you in most places, Ed Hayes said. And algae doesn't cloud the water as it does in some ponds, he said.
 ''This won't be Disney or Six Flags, more of a Huck Finn look, so when you walk through the gates, you will be transported back in time,'' Ed Hayes said after climbing out of the water, as he packed his wet suit into a bag.
 Even though the quarries have been designated a National Historic Landmark, the town, as owner, is allowed to develop them as it wants, since the town is not receiving federal assistance. But Portland, according to Susan Bransfield, the first selectwoman, has stipulated that the Hayeses not alter the area too much, like removing old walls or loose slabs. And there is a seven-member panel that meets with the developer.
 The project was approved by the Inland Wetlands Commission on April 4. The Hayeses said they plan to begin building a ticket office, changing rooms, a place to fill tanks with air, a concession stand and floating docks to have the park ready by Memorial Day weekend for their first customers. Ed Hayes says he expects 100,000 customers in the first year.
 According to the plan presented to the town, which calls for a $1 million investment and as many as 25 jobs, the park will also ultimately include a marina for canoes and kayaks, a fish farm run by Eastern Connecticut State University, swimming platforms, hand-pulled ferries and a campground. The town is helping grade some of the land and is giving the developer gravel for the entrance road.
 There will be separate areas that companies can use for team-building activities and that firefighters and paramedics can use for simulating rescue operations by scaling down the cliffs into the water.
 Until it is completely built, the property will look somewhat bleak. Gone are the buildings that used to house workers and the pastures where the oxen that hauled the stone out of the quarry used to graze, according to old photographs. 
 Instead, a row of asphalt storage tanks, set apart by a barbed-wire fence, stands between the quarries and the Connecticut River, blocking views of where schooners used to pick up the stone slabs and sail them around the world. 
 Rick Staub, with Point One Architects and Planners of Old Saybrook, which is designing the park, said that a line of trees will screen the tanks. 
 And eventually, the area alongside the river here, which stretches north of the Arrigoni Bridge, could be rezoned into a commercial district, said Ms. Bransfield ''We won't be putting another asphalt plant down there,'' she said.
 In exchange for granting the lease, which is to last for 25 years, Portland will receive 15 percent of the park's ticket sales. 
 The town could also benefit by seeing the feature that essentially put it on the map get an overdue cleanup. Under the deal, the Hayeses must remove garbage submerged in the deep water, which, according to local legend, was a favorite dumping ground of car thieves, petty crooks and mobsters.
 Indeed, over the last two years, while the Hayeses were trying to sell the idea to Portland's town leaders, they have removed 24,000 pounds of garbage, including air-conditioners, three cars, eight motorcycles, a safe filled with lottery tickets, boxes of ammunition and a Pepsi machine, the brothers said. 
 And there are still 12 cars down there that need to be removed because leaking gas and oil is polluting the water. 
 ''It was always the place where your parents told you not to go because it was dangerous,'' said Bob McDougall, director of the Ruth Callander House Museum of Portland History. ''It had been totally forgotten by the town.''
 The quarries' heyday stretched from 1870 to 1910, when the urban middle class began demanding the same supple brownstone, which could easily be carved into different shapes, that the wealthy had recently started using to build their homes, historians and architects said.
 With cities across the country clamoring for the stone, Portland's quarries (known for a higher-grade product than similar quarries in Longmeadow, Mass., and Cromwell, Conn., historians say) met the demand, producing as much as 21,000 cubic yards of it a year, Mr. McDougall said.
 Locally, it is visible all over the Connecticut River Valley, from Trinity Church in Portland to St. John's Church across the river in Middletown, where much of Wesleyan's campus along High Street is also made of Portland brownstone. The Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Arch in Bushnell Park in Hartford is also made of Portland brownstone, Mr. McDougall said. 
 But by the 1930's the industry was suffering, and the quarries were pretty much closed by 1940. 
 Less-expensive building materials like concrete and steel, coupled with a flood that caused the Connecticut River to pour into the quarries, made brownstone hard to get and somewhat obsolete. But brownstone quarrying didn't die entirely. 
 In 1994, Mike Meehan, a Cheshire resident, started a small quarrying business on a six-and-a-half-acre parcel on the north rim of the quarry pools, where he cuts 20,000 cubic feet of stone each year for clients looking to make repairs, like the police station in Middletown and the Cooper Union in New York.
 Mr. Meehan and his three employees cut stone with glittering diamond-wire chains that essentially whittle the soft rock away from the wall. Up until now, his only company has been the dinosaur footprints that occasionally are found. Even though he worried that park visitors could wander onto his site while dangerous machinery is running, he applauded the Hayeses' determination.
 ''They're very bright and hard working and not the kinds of guys to cut corners,'' Mr. Meehan said. ''If anybody can do it, they can.''
 Another neighbor is the Brownstone Quorum, a 130-member, nonprofit group formed just after Portland bought the quarries in 1999 to raise awareness of the history of the site. The group maintains a 30-acre ribbon of riverbank to the north of the quarries, where undesirable brownstone was once discarded. It contains a mile-and-a-half latticework of trails popular among dog-walkers and bird-watchers, said Michael Susca, a Portland resident and the group's president. But access to these trails will be harder under the terms of the park deal, he said.
 ''We're sad to lose the access to the quarry, but we're glad for the town in terms of its economic development,'' he said.
 Mr. Meehan's business notwithstanding, Portland's quarries have been the subject of business brainstorms before, and not all of them worked. In the late 1980's, for example, one proposal suggested cutting a channel from the quarries to the river to create moorings for boats.
 The cleanup of the quarries could allow a new generation to appreciate how one building material gave such a signature look to much of the area, said Charles Lockwood, a consultant on brownstone home restorations.
 "It's a terrific way to let people know where the stone in their homes comes from," he said.

SECTION: Section 8; Column 1; Sports Desk; Sports of The Times; Pg. 5
